story:
MONEY FAKETORY IS AN ONGOING ART PROJECT ABOUT MONEY MATTERS AND BEYOND

We are raising funds to create Installation work for our exhibition at Kuandu Biennial Taipei, Taiwan from September - December 2014

WHAT IS MONEY FAKETORY?

MONEY FAKETORY is an Art project.

It was started by a group of young artists discussing life and art careers. We want to bring the topic of " WE NEED TO TALK ABOUT MONEY " to the public.

MONEY FAKETORY encourages everyone to create their own art currencies which can be used in the MONEY FAKETORY banking system. Overlapping between Art and Money, we ask again " What is Art and How does capitalism effects Art its overall aspects"

we question the capitalism system which involved everything we concerned. 

MONEY FAKETORY has a website as a portal of exchange, where individual can exchange their money in any currencies with art note in any currencies.


ARTIST STATEMENT 

we are trying to experiment with various possibility to explore the frame of reference of MONEY, which is the heart of the economic system. MONEY FAKETORY will be a parody between real world and the art world and how it all is played and circulated. The key is to seek possibility to extend the meaning of money system which has a lot of stakes nowadays in the globalized world and how its nature represent other systems along the way.


HOW ART BANK NOTE IS MADE?


DETAIL OF PROJECT

We are raising fund to create Installation work for our exhibition at Kuandu Biennial Taipei, Taiwan from September - December 2014

We will build a small bank facilities, which have: 

  1. Money exchange and counter service booth
  2. Money making area
  3. Money Faketory store
  4. Gambling area
  5. Waiting area
The audiences are encourage to interact with all activities and learn about the story behind MONEY FAKETORY system in the exhibition
Exchange, Make, Deposit, Withdraw, Purchase merchandises and Gamble. 

  • The Kuandu Biennial is covering all curatorial costs, project management costs, promotional costs and administration costs + 1 Artist Fees and Partial Production Costs

WE ARE RAISING FUND FOR OUR TEAM AND PRODUCTION COSTS

  • Air Ticket for 5 members
  • Accommodations and Allowances for 3 weeks
  • Production Costs ( Merchandises for Store, All Banking documents, etc. )
  • Online + On-going Activities

PRIZES FOR SUPPORTER











* ART BANK NOTE with bank guarantee can be use at our shop, feel free to exchange, trade, circulate our art note and increase the liability of its currency

 

OUR TEAM

1. Kitima Chareeprasit, Young Curator
2. Donlakarn Sengboonton, Artist
3. Nuttapon Sawasdee, Artist
4. Henry Tan, Artist
5. Sina Wittayawiroj, Artist
6. Pisitakun Kuantalaeng, Artist

story:
BEE STORY DRESSES


                                   by Cheri A Ellis

                                                      www.cheriaellis.com

A Bee Story dress is created with original artwork that tells a story about the BEE and its awe-inspiring, collaborative work.......pollinating humanity's world and filling it with honey, color and abundance.

                                         "Bees work for the good of the whole"
Cheri A Ellis is a fashion designer and visual artist,  combining the 2 mediums in a project that creates awareness around the Bees and Colony Collapse Disorder.
                                                 www.facebook/cheri/ellis1


How does the dress tell a story about the Bee?

It begins with a story about a Bee .....and then a painting is created to illustrate the story ........



A graphite sketch  (below), digitally edited into a Bee galaxy. This story is about how  Bees collaborate and work together to make a golden sweet product that is             nourishing for them, and for the whole planet. A story about seed planting and making dreams come true, working together as one, for the 'good of the whole', and                                                     for the good of the planet.

               fashion look book @ www.NOTJUSTALABEL.com/CHERI_A_ELLIS

A painting named "Ether Bees" (below) , as Bees are truly celestial in the heavenly ways  they dance to communicate their needs to each other. The zig zag line is the                         'Waggle Dance', and is the pattern of their dance movement.



Three designs were digitally created from the painting "Ether Bees", and made into fabric, the dress below was designed and created to use the three designs in the most interesting way.



            fashion Look Book @ www.NOTJUSTALABEL.com/CHERI_A_ELLIS


                        The fabric design made from the "Ether Bees" painting.




The "Yellow Star Seed" painting made a nice collar for the dress, calico bias adds a     touch of 'sweet', and East Indian sequined clusters were added for the pollen.


    A backpack and grocery tote were made from the fabric, with Bee fabric lining.




                                          A wallet made with the Bee fabric.



The inside of the wallet is lined with fabrics from different Bee Story paintings, and                                 small Bee cards that say "Love for the Bees" 

                                             Brilliant Blue Bee
                                           Bioluminescent Bee
                                                   Trinity Bee 
                                        Blood Moon Queen Bee                                                                                      Day of the Dead Bee                                                                                          Celestial Hive Bee                                                                                            Boom Dragon Bee



              You can see the last 2 years of this project unfolding on facebook                                                                www.facebook.com/cheri/ellis.com

    

                    How did the idea come about?

The idea came to Cheri after she found herself creating a lot of 'Yellow and Black' 
the "Day of the Dead Bee"
"I had come to this point in my life, in my evolution as an artist, where I needed to re-direct my work and use it to give voice to a social cause I felt passionate about. The yellow / black palette was pretty clear about bringing my attention to the Bees, and the idea of  'A Canary in a Coal Mine'. I studied the Bee, learned about Colony                          Collapse Disorder, and began creating art about the Bees."


  the "Tribal Bee"
   She came up with idea of digitally re-creating the paintings, having the designs                                     printed onto fabric, and sewing them into dresses.

the "Blood Moon Queen Bee"
"I loved the idea of creating a dress that told a story! After I began to learn more about the Bees, I realized that their lifestyle is an amazing example of love and                 unity, and one that humanity could learn from in these times of severe environmental duress. I have always loved to create around 'the flower', I work with  abundant color creatively,  so the project has been a perfect fit for me, and one                 that has simply flowed out of me with much pleasure and true purpose."


                                  Product Details


  • Every item is handmade.
  • A custom made dress is a very special process, it requires a unique commitment  and involvement by the client, especially by mail order.
  • Dyes are eco friendly, and the printing process is chemical free.
  • All dresses and accessories can be made from any Bee Story design.
  • With every item comes a card with its Bee Story.


The "Brilliant Blue Bee" dress (above),  and the underskirt made of sheer silk organza, inspired by the Bee wing, hangs just below the bottom of the dress. Below, a second digital version of the painting. 



     

           What is the Current Stage of the Project?

The entire process has been developed and fine-tuned. From the Bee story, to artwork, through the digital editing, fabric printing, designing of the piece, and the                                 creating of the dress, as well as the accessories.
Networking has been established, and will progress so the project can deliver its                              message, and find its home with those it can inspire.
                Four Bee Fabric Dresses have been fully designed and created.
             Many paintings have been created, with endless digital possibilities.
                              The accessories can be found in an Etsy shop.

      Fashion Show  / POLLINATION / August 2015                                                  Is in the works




                Production and delivery of Rewards

Production and delivery will take approximately 3 - 5 months. This is what happens during that time.

Week   1 -4     /   fabric is ordered, Bee Cards cards sent

Week   5 - 8    /  producing 

Week   9 - 11   /  shipping

Week  12 - 14  /  dispatch rewards to customers



                         Why  Do I Need Money?
I have spent the last two years developing this project.  I need resources to create       stock, upgrade technical equipment, and time for networking and marketing.
    I would like to develop a small business that is like a Bee hive, one that creates            clothing in a way that is healthy for the planet, is empowering and fair with its workers, and provides a basic need that restores the integrity of humanity's desire                                         to self express in a way that is whole. 
This funding will help support another year of development. Progressively there will                          need to be more funding as next steps are taken.

                                 Crowd funding is very Bee like


                          Can I help in other ways?

Yes! Please spread the word amongst your friends and family. Share the campaign                       on Facebook, tell your favorite bloggers. Every bit helps.

                                            And just for fun ...


          "A Boom Dragon Bee Carrying a Yellow Star Seed Flower"


                THANK YOU!

A story about seed planting and making dreams come true, working together as one, for the 'good of the whole', and                                                     for the good of the planet.



               fashion look book @ www.NOTJUSTALABEL.com/CHERI_A_ELLIS


A painting named "Ether Bees" (below) , as Bees are truly celestial in the heavenly ways  they dance to communicate their needs to each other. The zig zag line is the                         'Waggle Dance', and is the pattern of their dance movement.




Three designs were digitally created from the painting "Ether Bees", and made into fabric, the dress below was designed and created to use the three designs in the most interesting way.






            fashion Look Book @ www.NOTJUSTALABEL.com/CHERI_A_ELLIS

                        The fabric design made from the "Ether Bees" painting.



The "Yellow Star Seed" painting made a nice collar for the dress, calico bias adds a     touch of 'sweet', and East Indian sequined clusters were added for the pollen.



    A backpack and grocery tote were made from the fabric, with Bee fabric lining.



                                          A wallet made with the Bee fabric.



The inside of the wallet is lined with fabrics from different Bee Story paintings, and                                 small Bee cards that say "Love for the Bees" 


                                             Brilliant Blue Bee                                           Bioluminescent Bee                                                   Trinity Bee                                         Blood Moon Queen Bee                                                                                      Day of the Dead Bee                                                                                          Celestial Hive Bee                                                                                            Boom Dragon Bee



              You can see the last 2 years of this project unfolding on facebook                                                                www.facebook.com/cheri/ellis.com
    
                    How did the idea come about?

The idea came to Cheri after she found herself creating a lot of 'Yellow and Black' 



the "Day of the Dead Bee"
"I had come to this point in my life, in my evolution as an artist, where I needed to re-direct my work and use it to give voice to a social cause I felt passionate about. The yellow / black palette was pretty clear about bringing my attention to the Bees, and the idea of  'A Canary in a Coal Mine'. I studied the Bee, learned about Colony                          Collapse Disorder, and began creating art about the Bees."




  the "Tribal Bee"
   She came up with idea of digitally re-creating the paintings, having the designs                                     printed onto fabric, and sewing them into dresses.




the "Blood Moon Queen Bee"


"I loved the idea of creating a dress that told a story! After I began to learn more about the Bees, I realized that their lifestyle is an amazing example of love and                 unity, and one that humanity could learn from in these times of severe environmental duress. I have always loved to create around 'the flower', I work with  abundant color creatively,  so the project has been a perfect fit for me, and one                 that has simply flowed out of me with much pleasure and true purpose."


                                  Product Details



Every item is handmade.

A custom made dress is a very special process, it requires a unique commitment  and involvement by the client, especially by mail order.


Dyes are eco friendly, and the printing process is chemical free.


All dresses and accessories can be made from any Bee Story design.

With every item comes a card with its Bee Story.








The "Brilliant Blue Bee" dress (above),  and the underskirt made of sheer silk organza, inspired by the Bee wing, hangs just below the bottom of the dress. Below, a second digital version of the painting. 





     

           What is the Current Stage of the Project?


The entire process has been developed and fine-tuned. From the Bee story, to artwork, through the digital editing, fabric printing, designing of the piece, and the                                 creating of the dress, as well as the accessories.

Networking has been established, and will progress so the project can deliver its                              message, and find its home with those it can inspire.
                Four Bee Fabric Dresses have been fully designed and created.
             Many paintings have been created, with endless digital possibilities.
                              The accessories can be found in an Etsy shop.

      Fashion Show  / POLLINATION / August 2015                                                  Is in the works








                Production and delivery of Rewards

Production and delivery will take approximately 3 - 5 months. This is what happens during that time.
Week   1 -4     /   fabric is ordered, Bee Cards cards sent
Week   5 - 8    /  producing 
Week   9 - 11   /  shipping
Week  12 - 14  /  dispatch rewards to customers



                         Why  Do I Need Money?

I have spent the last two years developing this project.  I need resources to create       stock, upgrade technical equipment, and time for networking and marketing.
    I would like to develop a small business that is like a Bee hive, one that creates            clothing in a way that is healthy for the planet, is empowering and fair with its workers, and provides a basic need that restores the integrity of humanity's desire                                         to self express in a way that is whole. 
This funding will help support another year of development. Progressively there will                          need to be more funding as next steps are taken.
                                 Crowd funding is very Bee like




                          Can I help in other ways?

Yes! Please spread the word amongst your friends and family. Share the campaign                       on Facebook, tell your favorite bloggers. Every bit helps.



                                            And just for fun ...



          "A Boom Dragon Bee Carrying a Yellow Star Seed Flower"


                THANK YOU!

story:
What's Summerfest?

With arts rapidly disappearing from today's school systems and children being forced into the adult world sooner and sooner, the imagination is being left by the wayside.

Summerfest provides a break for about 400 children from the Warren, Ohio area annually. It is two-weeks of creative art workshops, designed to inspire and encourage youngsters, from four years and up, in the arts.

The highly imaginative, age-grouped, workshops are organized around a unifying theme and taught by qualified professional teaching and working artist-instructors from the surrounding area.  This year's program will be held in the last two weeks of June.

Summerfest also sends instructors off-site to several participating children’s organizations, at no cost to the organization or to their students.

We'd like your help in sponsoring this program, where children can spend two weeks just being kids, coloring outside the lines without consequences and opening their minds to creativity.

This year's Summerfest: Fiber Makes Art!

Many materials are used by artists to create their work….stone is carved, wood is carved, sawn and assembled … metal is hammered, melted and poured into molds … clay from the riverbed is formed by hand and molded into shape. 

Many artists choose to use softer, more easily pliable materials for their works.  Fibers from animals and plants are manipulated in any number of ways.  In their simplest forms they are twisted, spun, and woven into fabrics, mats and baskets.  Paper (made from wood fibers and discarded cloth) is used in many artistic ways, from origami to pop-up cards to unique designer clothing and jewelry.  We will be taking time this year to look at the ways something so near to us in our everyday lives can be transformed by the creative spirit.

About the Trumbull Art Gallery: Began in 1957 as Trumbull Art Guild, by area artists to support each other and dedicated to engaging the community in the arts. Summerfest began as a TAG program in 2004, it has grown from 60 participants to over 400 annually.


What We Need:

Funding raised will be used for art supplies and scholarships. Since TAG, is a 501(c)3 non-profit, we rely on the generosity of donors for everything from paintbrushes to glue bottles.

Currently Summerfest workshops are available at a very nominal fee. Scholarships are also available. Funding will be used to offset class fees and provide more scholarships for children in the area who would otherwise be unable to attend.

If the full goal of $3,000 is not completely reached the funding will still be used in the same manner.


Other Ways You Can Help

This arts festival for children culminates on the final day in a uniquely creative noon hour Summerfest Art Parade around Courthouse Square in downtown Warren with all the participants, their family and friends, carrying and/or wearing their fanciful creations.  You are invited to join the parade.  Family friendly activities follow for about an hour after the parade.

Feel free to friend TAG on Facebook for updates on other gallery and Summerfest events.

story:
Dear friends,

Associazione Vivere Castellazzo (“Living Castellazzo Association”) is a no-profit italian group active in Castellazzo (Milan), whose goal is to promote the italian culture in a beautiful area close to Milan: “Groane” natural park and the ancient buildings to be found there.

The Italian Jazz Fest is an Art 'n Music event wich will take place in Villa Arconati, a beautiful seventeenth-century Villa within the Groane park. The purpose  of the Fest is to promote the italian talent with twelve concerts in June 2015, during the EXPO 2015 time, and to contribute to the restauration of the Villa. The entrance to the concerts will be on offer and the proceeds will be donated to the restoration of the Villa.

The implementation will require a great economic effort - each concert will cost about 7,000 euros – and it is not easy to find in Italy funding for cultural projects. This is the reason why we are looking for contributions around the world. 

Be part of this project and we'll realize a dream!


P.S. Please share this link even if you can´t contribute in form of one of the perks…tell everyone you know - that already helps a lot ! 

Associazione Vivere Castellazzo - the Committee

the painter Paolo Fabbro, first sponsor of the Festival

story:
What is Stazione di Topolò - Postaja Topolove

 

Stazione Topolò - Postaja Topolove is a laboratory for the arts and for thinking that focuses its activities in the small village of Topolò / Topolove, in the municipality of Grimacco (Udine), at the extreme border between Italy and Slovenia.

 

Topolò paid a high price after the second world war because of the Iron Curtain, the cost of which was the emigration of 90% of its inhabitants as a consequence of the restrictions to normal aspects of life imposed by the  post-1945 political strategies on the area. Topolò is somehow a symbol of the contradictions of the twentieth century, with its isolation, typical of the mountain villages, reinforced by its "damned border."  It is in such a wounded place that art was thought to have the opportunity to express its ethical value, detached from its entertaining and worldly aspects. Stazione di Topolò - Postaja Topolove – is not a festival and does not include traveling shows but only site-specific projects. In Topolò, experimentation is rooted in tradition and into a worn out culture that is still very rich and archaic.  It is not a show and there are no exhibition times.  Everything takes place in the squares, in the streets, in the fields, in the woods and in private homes, using what is available. In this way, Topolò is neither directly affected by the events, nor is it passive to them, but rather the driving force behind them.

 

The people who work in Topolò lodge in the houses around of the village, living as locals. In Topolò for many decades hospitality was forbidden. The roles of the artist and the audience are mixed; many projects have been realised through a collaboration between the artists and the guests of the village, or between artists and local children, giving everyone a leading role. Everything takes place in a very informal way.

 

Stazione di Topolò has drawn the attention of the international media who are fascinated by the utopian ideals of this project which combines art, thought, social life and economic revival. The organisers are gathered in the not-for-profit Association Topolò-Topoluove.

 

 

 

Why help Stazione di Topolò - Postaja Topolove?

Since 2004, the Friuli Venezia Giulia region has supported Stazione Topolò - Postaja Topolove with a small grant which has guaranteed its survival. In 2011 funding was reduced by 33%. For 2013, the Regional Council has chosen to reduce drastically its cultural fundings: they are now cut by 50%. With the remaining sum it is no longer possible to support any activity, not even to cover the basic expenses. All the funds raised by this campaign will be used exclusively in the production of cultural activities taking place during the year and supported by Stazione di Topolò - Postaja Topolove.

 

Cos'è la Stazione di Topolò - Postaja Topolove

 Stazione di Topolò - Postaja Topolove è un laboratorio per le arti e per il pensiero che concentra le sue attività nel piccolo borgo di Topolò/Topolove, frazione del comune di Grimacco (Udine), all'estremo confine tra Italia e Slovenia. Topolò ha pagato un prezzo altissimo nel dopoguerra a causa della cortina di ferro, un prezzo che è ben visibile nella perdita, per emigrazione, del 90% dei suoi abitanti a causa dei divieti a una vita normale imposti dalla sua posizione geografica e dalle strategie politiche post 1945. Topolò è in  qualche modo un simbolo delle contraddizioni del secolo breve, con il suo isolamento, tipico dei borghi montani, accentuato dal "maledetto confine". Proprio in luogo tanto ferito si è pensato che l'arte avesse occasione di esprimere il suo valore etico, lontano dall'aspetto mondano e di intrattenimento. La Stazione non è un festival, non accoglie spettacoli itineranti ma solo progetti pensati per il luogo.

A Topolò la sperimentazione si innesta sulla tradizione e su un tessuto culturale molto provato ma ricchissimo e arcaico.

Non è una mostra, non c'è alcun momento espositivo. Tutto si svolge nelle piazzette, lungo le vie, nei prati, nel bosco, nelle case private, utilizzando quello che c'è, senza stravolgere il luogo che diventa il motore principale e non lo scenario passivo di quanto accade. 

Chi opera a Topolò viene ospitato nelle case del paese, vive come un abitante del paese. A Topolò per molti decenni l'ospitalità era interdetta. 

I progetti vedono spesso la collaborazione di altri artisti e ricercatori presenti in paese, dei ragazzi della zona, mescolando i ruoli di artista e spettatore e facendo di tutti dei protagonisti. Tutto si svolge in maniera molto informale. 

 La Stazione ha suscitato l'interesse dei media internazionali, affascinati dall'utopia del progetto che unisce arte, pensiero, vita sociale, rinascita economica.

Gli organizzatori sono radunati nell'Associazione Topolò-Topoluove, associazione no-profit.  

 

Perché chiediamo fondi?

 Dal 2004 la Regione Friuli Venezia Giulia ha sostenuto Stazione di Topolò/Postaja Topolove con un finanziamento che, pur ridotto rispetto a quello di un festival, ne ha garantito la sopravvivenza. Nel 2011 il finanziamento è stato ridotto del 33%. Per il 2013, la Giunta Regionale ha scelto di dare un taglio netto proprio alla voce Cultura e la riduzione è stata ancora più massiccia: il 50%. Con la cifra rimasta non è possibile svolgere alcuna attività, nemmeno per coprire le spese primarie. 

I fondi che giungeranno saranno esclusivamente utilizzati nella realizzazione delle attività culturali che si svolgono durante l'intero arco dell'anno sotto l'egida di Stazione di Topolò/Postaja Topolove.

story:
Short Summary

I am bringing my show, "Who I am" to Grand Rapids, Michigan and this coming fall/winter. Originally it was planned for September but due to time and space availability I have pushed it back. This show encompasses a unique way of story telling through art; dancing, acting, live painting and live music. It tells the story of persevering through hardships in pursuit of a life purpose. It takes the audience through the wide range laughter, frustration, sadness and hope.
 
Because this production received great feed back when it was done in Hollywood, I have decided to take it to different cities and make it a national performance. After performing in Michigan this fall I plan to take this show to Chicago and New York in the near future. This production can not be done without your help! The details are below. 

 

What I Need & What You Get

All details are NOT finalized until the theater receives my deposit.

Who:
Jerry Rodriguez will be the featured artist and will have back up dancers as well as live musicians. 

When:
Aiming for Friday, October 5th 

Where:
Grand Rapids Wealthy Theater, which seats about 400 people

Cost:
In order to do the entire production it will cost me:

$1,500 - which includes, theater rental, dress rehearsal, tech, sound, light, professional recording, marketing, and box office

$200-300 Canvas and paint

$250-400 - Travel fees

How:
This is where I need your help. If you would like to donate and be a part of a major story please start here and sponser me. Small donations make a big difference too!!!

REWARD!!!
I will be giving out my art work for my top donors. 

Top donor: One of my art pieces of your choice or request a painting/drawing to be done and reserved seats towards the front for friends and family.
Second highest donor: Choice of one painting and reserved seats towards the front for friends and family. 
Third Highest donor: Choice of one painting. 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute financially, please help me get the word out!

story:
Marian Wantoła (ur. 2 lutego 1926 w Bielsku) - Człowiek legenda Naszego miasta, który współtworzył jedną z najbardziej rozpoznawanych polskich postaci animowanych Reksia żyje w ciężkich warunkach. Pomóżmy, pokażmy, że dbamy o tych, którzy tworzą dorobek naszej kultury, zwłaszcza, że jest On najstarszym animatorem w Polsce pod względem stażu pracy. Reprezentował w pojedynkę nasz kraj na Expo 2010, został również odznaczony Kryształowym Sercem PCK.

2,5 sekundy filmu dziennie – rozmowa z Marianem Wantołą, rysownikiem i animatorem

Brak wody, ogrzewania i grzyb na ścianie. Tak żyje słynny animator Bolka i Lolka

Dostępna będzie relacja ze spożytkowania zebranych środków.

 

-----

Marian Wantola (born 2 Feb 1926 in Bielsk, Poland) - a veteran Polish animator and cartoonist who played a vital role in creating and animating some of the most famous Polish cartoons (such as "Reksio" or "Bolek i Lolek"), is now living in though conditions and never got any royalties for the innumerable contributions to Polish culture he made. He is the oldest living Polish animator right now, he single-handedly represented Poland on Expo 2000, and was awarded a "Krysztalowe Serce" ("crystal heart") order from the Polish Red Cross. He now spends his time drawing his characters for sick and poor children in orphanages, and has no support whatsoever. Let's help him out! Please see the video above for details about Marian's current status.

story:
About Me

My name is Raven Creature, and I am an artist who has lived in New Orleans for eleven years. I started with a pencil, and moved on to painting and sculpture, but came back to the pencil. It's simple yet complex, limiting oneself to the pencil and simple paper. But within these confines can come a look through someone else's eyes. I'm a decent painter, but pencil is what I'm best at.


The Project

Since October 10 I started a new series of portraits of famous authors. Each one of these is a pleasure to draw. I'm hoping to sell quality signed prints of them, but I don't have the money to make the prints so I've started this campaign. I'm also selling the originals, and more, for contributions.

I've come up with all sorts of fun rewards for your donation, from a print, an original, or even drawing lessons from me if you live in town!

The funds go directly into my costs, which are not great, namely printing the prints and the packaging. This will also give me a chance to see which prints I will need to print more or less of, dictated by demand.

At the end of the campaign all of the completed author drawings will go up to my solo show on January 11 at Byrdie's Gallery here in New Orleans. Therefore all originals will be available once the show is down, mid February.

I hope that this project will excite you as much as it does me! I have so far completed 18 original author drawings, and I'm not done yet! As the campaign progresses I will post more drawings as soon as they are complete. And, one of the perks is that you can decide which author I do next!


The Authors

I started with Franz Kafka, author of “The Metamorphosis”. I just love his viewpoint throughout the entire story! The photo I used as reference was fairly flat so I had to “make up” some of the features.


I wanted to honor one of the creepiest writers, H.P. Lovecraft for inventing (discovering) Cthulhu. 

The original for this is still available: ignore what it says for the "Art Lover" perk. For some reason I wrote in Lovecraft instead of Burroughs.


Next I drew Edna St Vincent Millay, the lyrical poet and playwright.


Then I wanted to do someone who was a prominent figure in some magickal circles, so I drew Aleister Crowley.


Emily Dickinson was hard because the best photo I could find of her was of poor quality and she looked rather flat. I did what I did with Kafka, made up her features as I imagined her to be.


Going back to horror writers, I did Stephen King for shits and giggles. The glasses were a challenge.


Living in New Orleans I just had to next draw Anne Rice, who started off my love of vampires when The Vampire Lestat first went to paperback. She was hard because I don't try to draw teeth unless I have to, and 99% of pictures of her were of her with this lovely smile!


Ayn Rand is a figure that everyone has a strong reaction to. You either love or hate her politics. She is known for The Fountainhead and Atlas Shrugged.


William S. Burroughs is a lot of things, to a lot of people. I first knew him as author of Junkie and Naked Lunch, which I saw in the theater when it came out. Brilliant, mad. I loved doing each wrinkle! This one may be sold!


Anais Nin is known for, among other things, her erotica and journals. She is the woman that the movie Henry and June was written by.


Lou Reed, beloved musician, songwriter, and yes, an author was an immense icon to an entire generation, and then some. This original is sold already!


And, did you think I forgot my all time favorite author, Edgar Allen Poe? Here he is!


The French author Colette, by commission. You can commission one, too!



The Beat poet, Jack Kerouac.


One of my personal faves, science fiction author Philip K. Dick!


Mary Shelley, author of Frankenstein.


The beloved author, Neil Gaiman!



And my most recent author and playwright, Tennessee Williams.



My tools. An 9” x 12” toned paper drawing pad, a 2B pencil, a 6B pencil, a white Conte pencil, a gummy eraser and an eraser pen. That's it. I like to keep it simple.


Part of my studio.

story:
"London Structural Sound Project" by Florian Tuercke

Artist Florian Tuercke together with arebyte gallery intends to transform the area of Hackney Wick, East London and its surroundings, to one with the highest density of public microphones in the world. The project is participatory in its nature and invites the public to take a crucial part in its production through the distribution of the microphones thought out the vicinity of the gallery and in return offers an unheard experience of their local area and of the city of London in general.

The Microphones are given free of charge on first come first get basis or reserved as part of the crowd funding campaign.

The artist will assemble 300 mini-contact microphones which will be handed out to visitors of arebyte gallery to be installed in different locations in the vicinity of the gallery. The contact-microphones record sound-waves within solid materials and enable the listener to hear sounds which are normally inaudible to the human ear. Each microphone will be packed in a bag containing simple instructions and mounting material.

This is how the project goes:

As a visitor of the gallery you will receive a bag that contains one microphone, mounting material and instructions (Few bags will be placed in community centres and libraries). You are encouraged to explore public space with the intention to find a suitable spot for mounting your microphone.

You send a photo of the installed microphone and a precise description of its location (street address or GPS-tag) by e-mail. Your microphone will then be published in an online map.Throughout the project, a recording-team will visit all microphones and record sound-samples which will later be published as well. 

During the project a pre-amplified kits will be available for hire at arebyte gallery with which you can take along with you and visit the microphones and listen to them onsite.


Example for a contact microphone 

The main participatory stage is with the distribution of the microphones; each visitor to arebyte gallery will receive one microphone and will be asked to install it anywhere they please (within 1km radios from the gallery). Each microphone will be visually documented by the same person or the project team and will be added onto an interactive map which will be displayed in arebyte gallery.

A recording-team, consisting of the artist and collaborators, will visit each site and take a unique field sample of each place.Each microphone will have its own characteristics; its location and the material it’s mounted on, thus giving a unique sound-scape of the city. The sound of the city will then be used by the artist (together with other sonic art collaborators) to be re-composed within the gallery space to create a macro sound map of the city. Another aspect of the public participation will be access to a series of guided tours with a set of pre-amplified headphones which will allow the audience to live hear the city’s breath and heartbeat (the audience will also be able to rent the equipment on individual tours using the maps).

The interactive maps (which will be online and projected in the gallery) will grow and expand as the microphones are implemented. The map will feature the sounds and will be as an interactive sound-installation in itself. The audience will be able play with the sounds, discover and compose as they wish. This interactive sound-map will remain after the project as online-version.

 

Possible installation method *


This project apart from existing for artistic endeavour will also encourage the public to engage with their local area, re-examine the streets and structure of their surroundings and eventually aims to deliver new experiences of familiar neighbourhoods and public spaces.

The project aims to achieve a world-record in mapping structure-borne urban sounds and to instil pride in all involved with the great ambitions of the artwork, which relies more heavily on public engagement than capital input.

The project is planned to launch on the 22nd of May and run until the 13th of June.

*Images are from a smaller project that was held by Florian Tuercke in Turku (Finland) in 2011 and from a workshop which was part of Tuerckes last years project in Zaragoza (Spain) http://urban-audio.org/zaragoza.html, which was dealing with the musical transformation of traffic noise.

You find more examples of previous works by Florian Tuercke on his website: http://floriantuercke.net/works.html


follow us on Facebook for news about the progress of the preparations: https://www.facebook.com/structural.sound.project


Project powered by arebyte gallery

story:
I (R.Ariel) have been touring Canada and the USA since March 15th, 2015 and the tour will end on July 8th, 2015. Along the way, I have been writing a book, "In North America," about what these experiences have been like. A stream of consciousness and a look into touring independently. I explain what it is like to grow up in Phoenix, my families past and many more topics. I have also been taking photos to accompany these words. Paper Cut Press (NY) and I have partnered to put this book out on September 29th. I am also completing and recording a new album, "This World," that will be released with "In North America." After the release I will tour Europe for 2 months! I can't do any of this without your help!

A very crucial part of this crowd funding campaign is getting the resources in order to record, mix and master my own music. This is something that I attempted while recording "Life As It Seems" (2014 with Bri White) and also "Histories" (2014) on my own. Because of my lack of resources, I have been frequently forced to borrow other musicians recording gear and computers to achieve the sound I want. I believe if given the proper resources to record my own material, I could create higher quality sounds and have the time to mix and master them properly. Here is an example of a song that I recorded, mixed and mastered myself.

https://soundcloud.com/rarielmusic/phoenix-unwise

Here are some articles about my latest album, 2015 tour and upcoming book with Papercut Press:

https://oneam.squarespace.com/interviews/#/r-ariel/

http://londonfuse.ca/blog/10969
http://beatroute.ca/tag/r-ariel/
http://noisefestival.com/user/unwise/work/phoenix
http://www.vueweekly.com/music-notes-apr-16-apr-22/
http://flymagazine.net/go-3-live-music-picks-weekend/
http://swelltonemusic.com/2015/05/digging-deeper-r-ariel-changer/

http://www.thelaurelofasheville.com/editorial/web-exclusive-musician-r-ariel-makes-asheville-debut-at-the-crow-quill

http://onlineathens.com/marquee/2015-06-04/lush...

Here is a TV interview I did:

http://www.knoe.com/news/goodmorningarklamiss/h...

Here are some quotes that have been said of my music, writing and performances:

"This sounds like what nostalgia feels like. Or a memory. This piece has an illusive serenity to it which fills the room." - Brian Eno on R.Ariel's music

"Really like the tone and recording on this, mystical and intriguing. The singers voice is really seductive and the visuals draws me in." Thris Tian on R.Ariel

"Sufficiently feral." -Jeremy Rigsby (Media City Film Festival) on R.Ariel

"The terse charm of a blue pineapple in aquatic free fall--endlessly, and its meditations on the post-modern tempest above the waves."  - Tj Orloski on R.Ariel's music

"A rose amongst thorns." - Mary Crocker on R.Ariel

"Its that fire, like two toke and done type shit...but you just keep rippin'." - Tristan Torres on R.Ariel's music

"I heard Brian Eno likes her music, that is pretty sweet." - Monika Kuntar on R.Ariel

"You seem kind." -Stranger in New York on R.Ariel giving him a cigarette

"Working with R.Ariel required a lot of pubic hair maintenance." -Katie O on starring in R.Ariel's music video

"Can't stop listening to R.Ariel's album "Changer." I love it, my cat loves it, everybody loves it! Listen to her music." - Kayleigh Mackay (MoonMuseum) on R.Ariel's latest album.

"There’s something unwittingly surreal about the moment you come up for air
after drowning in what an album has elegantly drenched you in- and
track-for-track, R.ariel has an elegance remarkable enough to give you
such wholesome familiarity with her." - Micah Dailey of Moone Records on R.Ariel's latest album

"Changer" is going to be that album that everybody refers back to as their first "R.Ariel album" when everybody else is like four albums later and they're trying to sound cool. - Tara Logsdon of Bearmy on R.Ariel's latest album

"I fully endorse R.Ariel as the future of music." - Tim Clapp of Kingfisher Bluez Records on wanting to put out R.Ariel's music on vinyl.

"R.Ariel's music is the lovechild of Beyonce and Charles Manson. It sets your booty to shaking and sends chills down your spine." - Kristofer Westfall on R.Ariel's music

"Her songs are profound like the wind upon which travels the will-o-the-wisp." - m. craig on R.Ariel's music

"I've been listening to R.Ariel's album for the last three hours, it brings me immense joy, it is the perfect music for listening to late at night while I'm alone on my birthday contemplating my age. Finally alone, no distraction other then myself and her voice. Sailing through the winds of time on the gentle waves of her guitar, the smell of salt water even though I'm hundreds of miles from the nearest sea. The sun on my skin even though it's dark. The dryness of the air doesn't bother me now, I feel submersed." - Douglas Kent James (guitar builder extraordinaire) on R.Ariel's latest album

"Do you know what reverb smells like…? Rachel does. Do you know how echo tastes…? Rachel does. Do you desire your brain to loop through your earballs…? Rachel will help you." - Thaddeus Hink (photographer) on R.Ariel's music

"R. Ariels music is an anthem for those facing their own crippling self doubt or sad girl/boi inclinations; seeing/hearing her play reminds you that you can do anything no matter how friggin depressed you are" - Nicole Milk Shake on R.Ariel's performances and music

"If you are more than 5 minutes late, she will leave you behind covered in dust from her Oldsmobile's tires. Don't confuse her beautiful ethereal music for someone who will tolerate your shit." - Sam Gratz (jewelery designer) on R.Ariel

"R.Ariel's music is if modern folk took a time machine back to the 1920s." - Steph Carrico (owner of Trunk Space Phx) on R.Ariel's music

"When I listen to r.ariel's music I am instantly sucked into an infinite vortex of dreamy sound waves and soothing melodies." - Ian Clontz (photographer) on R.Ariel's music

"Here come the warm beats." - John Falvo on R.Ariel's music

"Good songwriting and sleepy psychedelia. Exactly what our dreams should sound like." - Tyler Broderick of Diners on R.Ariel's music

Here is an entry from "In North America."

"05/03/15

Sometimes, the suburbs remind me of cages. Or traps. Or a very comfortable jail cell. The lawns all need attention or that's what everyone thinks. The cars are all shiny like brand new teeth. The fences are perfectly carved to create a boundary where you exist and where they do. The golden retrievers all smile happy when you walk by and wag their tails and the middle aged man smiles at you too. They will give you a cup of sugar if you ask. The mortgage is too high, that's why they stay. But in a couple years things will be different. That's what they say. I nod and agree. I'm a deer in a head lights here. Or maybe I'm like a raccoon. You don't see me very often but when you do, I am probably picking through your garbage. You don't see me often but when you do, I'm hiding from you. A rat behind you. Or a moth on your window. The wasps nest that you are trying to rid your home of. The flies that cover your molding fruit. Or the stain on the street you wish the city would take care of. You don't see me often but when you do, I am quiet. I try to blend in but my clothes don't fit right and my teeth a bit too crooked. My eyes dull and exhaustion on my face. They don't see me often but when they do, they wish I would leave the neighborhood and wave politely as I go. They wish I would."

Here is a sample of what "This World" will sound like.

https://soundcloud.com/rarielmusic/tracks-1


Break down of costs:
$1000 for recording equipment
$1000 for tickets to and from Europe
$1000 for rental car in Europe
$1800 for book printing
$900 for touring gear
$300 Indiegogo fee

If you would like to make a physical donation in the form of plane tickets (I know some of you got those good hook ups), recording gear, etc. Please get in touch at rachelarielcrocker@gmail.com and we can work something out!

If we, for some insane reason, go over the 6000 dollars we are attempting to raise, all funds will be put towards making more copies of "In North America" and "This World" and making t-shirts. If we get to something real crazy like $8000, "This World" will be printed on vinyl through Kingfisher Bluez Records in Vancouver.

Thank you all forever.

Here is an example of a song that I recorded, mixed and mastered myself.https://soundcloud.com/rarielmusic/phoenix-unwise Here are some articles about my latest album, 2015 tour and upcoming book with Papercut Press:https://oneam.squarespace.com/interviews/#/r-ariel/http://londonfuse.ca/blog/10969 http://beatroute.ca/tag/r-ariel/ http://noisefestival.com/user/unwise/work/phoenix http://www.vueweekly.com/music-notes-apr-16-apr-22/ http://flymagazine.net/go-3-live-music-picks-weekend/ http://swelltonemusic.com/2015/05/digging-deeper-r-ariel-changer/http://www.thelaurelofasheville.com/editorial/web-exclusive-musician-r-ariel-makes-asheville-debut-at-the-crow-quillhttp://onlineathens.com/marquee/2015-06-04/lush...Here is a TV interview I did:http://www.knoe.com/news/goodmorningarklamiss/h...Here are some quotes that have been said of my music, writing and performances: "This sounds like what 
nostalgia feels like. Or a memory. This piece has an illusive serenity 
to it which fills the room." - Brian Eno on R.Ariel's music"Really like the tone and recording on this, mystical and intriguing. The
 singers voice is really seductive and the visuals draws me in." Thris Tian on R.Ariel"Sufficiently feral." -Jeremy Rigsby (Media City Film Festival) on R.Ariel"The terse charm of a blue pineapple in aquatic 
free fall--endlessly, and its meditations on the post-modern tempest 
above the waves."  - Tj Orloski on R.Ariel's music"A rose amongst thorns." - Mary Crocker on R.Ariel"Its that fire, like two toke and done type shit...but you just keep rippin'." - Tristan Torres on R.Ariel's music"I heard Brian Eno likes her music, that is pretty sweet." - Monika Kuntar on R.Ariel"You seem kind." -Stranger in New York on R.Ariel giving him a cigarette"Working with R.Ariel required a lot of pubic hair maintenance." -Katie O on starring in R.Ariel's music video "Can't stop listening to R.Ariel's album "Changer." I 
love it, my cat loves it, everybody loves it! Listen to her music." - Kayleigh Mackay (MoonMuseum) on R.Ariel's latest album."There’s something unwittingly surreal about the moment you come up for air
after drowning in what an album has elegantly drenched you in- and
track-for-track, R.ariel has an elegance remarkable enough to give you
such wholesome familiarity with her." - Micah Dailey of Moone Records on R.Ariel's latest album"Changer" is going to be that album that everybody refers back to as their first "R.Ariel album" when everybody else is like four albums later and they're trying to sound cool. - Tara Logsdon of Bearmy on R.Ariel's latest album"I fully endorse R.Ariel as the future of music." - Tim Clapp of Kingfisher Bluez Records on wanting to put out R.Ariel's music on vinyl. "R.Ariel's music is the lovechild of Beyonce and Charles Manson.  It sets your booty to shaking and sends chills down your spine." - Kristofer Westfall on R.Ariel's music"Her songs are profound like the wind upon which travels the will-o-the-wisp." - m. craig on R.Ariel's music"I've been listening to R.Ariel's album for the last three 
hours, it brings me immense joy, it is the perfect music for listening 
to late at night while I'm alone on my birthday contemplating my age. 
Finally alone, no distraction other then myself and her voice. Sailing 
through the winds of time on the gentle waves of her guitar, the smell 
of salt water even though I'm hundreds of miles from the nearest sea. 
The sun on my skin even though it's dark. The dryness of the air doesn't
 bother me now, I feel submersed." - Douglas Kent James (guitar builder extraordinaire) on R.Ariel's latest album"Do you know what reverb smells like…? Rachel does. Do 
you know how echo tastes…? Rachel does. Do you desire your brain to loop
 through your earballs…? Rachel will help you." - Thaddeus Hink (photographer) on R.Ariel's music"R. Ariels music is an anthem for those facing their 
own crippling self doubt or sad girl/boi inclinations; seeing/hearing 
her play reminds you that you can do anything no matter how friggin 
depressed you are" - Nicole Milk Shake on R.Ariel's performances and music"If you are more than 5 minutes late, she will leave you behind covered in dust from her Oldsmobile's tires. Don't confuse her beautiful ethereal music for someone who will tolerate your shit." - Sam Gratz (jewelery designer) on R.Ariel"R.Ariel's music is if modern folk took a time machine back to the 1920s." - Steph Carrico (owner of Trunk Space Phx) on R.Ariel's music
"When I listen to r.ariel's music I am instantly sucked into an infinite vortex of dreamy sound waves and soothing melodies." - Ian Clontz (photographer) on R.Ariel's music"Here come the warm beats." - John Falvo on R.Ariel's music
"Good songwriting and sleepy psychedelia. Exactly what our dreams should sound like." - Tyler Broderick of Diners on R.Ariel's musicHere is an entry from "In North America.""05/03/15Sometimes, the suburbs remind me of cages. Or traps. Or a very comfortable jail cell. The lawns all need attention or that's what everyone thinks. The cars are all shiny like brand new teeth. The fences are perfectly carved to create a boundary where you exist and where they do. The golden retrievers all smile happy when you walk by and wag their tails and the middle aged man smiles at you too. They will give you a cup of sugar if you ask. The mortgage is too high, that's why they stay. But in a couple years things will be different. That's what they say. I nod and agree. I'm a deer in a head lights here. Or maybe I'm like a raccoon. You don't see me very often but when you do, I am probably picking through your garbage. You don't see me often but when you do, I'm hiding from you. A rat behind you. Or a moth on your window. The wasps nest that you are trying to rid your home of. The flies that cover your molding fruit. Or the stain on the street you wish the city would take care of. You don't see me often but when you do, I am quiet. I try to blend in but my clothes don't fit right and my teeth a bit too crooked. My eyes dull and exhaustion on my face. They don't see me often but when they do, they wish I would leave the neighborhood and wave politely as I go. They wish I would."Here is a sample of what "This World" will sound like. https://soundcloud.com/rarielmusic/tracks-1Break down of costs:$1000 for recording equipment$1000 for tickets to and from Europe$1000 for rental car in Europe$1800 for book printing$900 for touring gear$300 Indiegogo feeIf you would like to make a physical donation in the form of plane tickets (I know some of you got those good hook ups), recording gear, etc. Please get in touch at rachelarielcrocker@gmail.com and we can work something out! If we, for some insane reason, go over the 6000 dollars we are attempting to raise, all funds will be put towards making more copies of "In North America" and "This World" and making t-shirts. If we get to something real crazy like $8000, "This World" will be printed on vinyl through Kingfisher Bluez Records in Vancouver. Thank you all forever.

story:
We Are Coloring Camelot

I'm Suzanna Stinnett, an author and artist lucky to live in the lush greenery of northern California. My environment is filled with imagery that begs to be drawn, and what could be better than creating books full of designs for others who like to color? 

I love drawing these images! The meditative comfort that many of us are finding with coloring is only surpassed by the calm relaxation I find while sketching, sculpting and inking these pieces. What a happy meeting of hearts!

Did you know coloring reduces your heart rate, produces friendly brain chemicals, and relieves stress? I like to think of everyone taking a nice long break (or lots of short breaks!) to color away, grow peaceful inside, and let the world breathe for an hour or two.

My drawing is influenced by Maxfield Parrish, Kandinsky, Hunterwasser, and Dr. Seuss, to name a few. I love scenes with a bit of whimsy that evoke a sense of story. Another great love of mine is architectural shapes. Many drawings in Hidden Realms include aspects of castles as well as fanciful versions of architectural design. Flowery swirls and leafy lanes in scenes of an imagined Camelot appear in this collection. Decorative bits of ancient kings and queens weave their way into patterns framed in handcrafted borders. My drawings contain "brain-friendly" repeating curves and varying lengths which contribute to the calming action of coloring.

I want my coloring books to be comfortable and reassuring, even if some images present a bit of a challenge. In addition to the more complex designs I call "Gallery" pieces, I've created more pages where you can freely experiment, archive your colors, and try things out without worrying about "making it look good." During this campaign I'll share samples of Gallery pieces, as well as "Simplers" (they take less time to complete than the Gallery pieces), and "Little Quicklys," which are perfect for a break in your day, a coloring party, or for the kids around the table. My "Color Keepers" have special shapes for comparing your colors, trying out new pens or pencils, and keeping your notes.

In the Special Set for this campaign, the Gallery pieces are printed on card stock good for framing, and the other pages are printed on heavy, durable paper for a great coloring experience.

Your help with the Coloring Camelot campaign will allow me to bring these drawings into a fine print form, ready for your pens and pencils.

Goals and Outcomes

The first goal is set at $750.00, which will allow me to bring Coloring Camelot's first set, "Hidden Realms," into print, as well as making it available through a number of distribution vehicles. 
Beyond the first goal, I'd like to continue with "Fog-Fed Gardens," a purse-sized coloring book that is made for travel. If we reach $2500, I'll be able to produce this special set and bring it to print. The images in "Fog-Fed Gardens" come straight from my walks around Marin county, and include visitors from farther north along the verdant Pacific coast. Gardens full of flowers and lovely salvaged creations also make up the smaller images which can be colored in a half hour or so.

There are more goals to come, so let's find out how many coloring enthusiasts are out there! 

Challenges

How do these images come into being? I begin with pencil sketches in my journal.  In order to create the repeating images that so many color-ers enjoy, I employ some digital techniques. Then the image gets printed, redrawn, and inked by hand. The extra steps take me to a sweet spot, where the lines are flowing, which I want to attain before I decide it is finished. 

Before anything gets drawn, however, I have to go off on a walk. Walking around Marin county and other points north, I find myself staring at endlessly entertaining gardens and structures, some traditional, some ridiculous, and many outrageously beautiful plantings. I may take a photo or sketch it on the spot. Sometimes, as I'm walking, I get an image in my head of a scene I want to draw. I'm captivated by certain shapes such as the fleur-de-lys and totem-like finials, so you may notice them here and there in my drawings. 

I also listen closely to coloring enthusiasts I've joined in online forums. I have learned a great deal about what makes a drawing appealing for this use, and especially what makes them meditative and healing to color. Thank you to all the participants in forums who make it easier to know what and how to draw images for you!

If you love to color but can't contribute right now, you are certainly welcome to help share the word about Coloring Camelot! Everyone is invited to use the share tools here on the campaign.

Thanks everyone! See you in the gardens!

Suzanna Stinnett

story:
I know what it's like to go hungry. I know what it's like to lose everything. But I also know what it's like to have everything change when someone lifted me up. Countless volunteers around the country give of their time and finances to help people that they may never meet, all without recognition or any form of compensation. Were it not for people like that, I wouldn't be here today.

This project is very personal to me. It's my attempt to repay those who have given me so much. At the same time, I hope to see the dialogue surrounding hunger change. It's not about statistics or some kind of political agenda - it's about people. So many folks are hurting and in need of a hand. By speaking with volunteers around the country and telling their stories, I hope to put a human face to the issue of hunger.

I believe that a strong community is one that looks out for the marginalized, the weak, and the hurting. Let's give them hope and recognize the men and women who work so hard to see that happen.

What the deuce is Ten Sixty-Six?

Ten Sixty-Six is the number of miles I will walk from my home in Columbus to reach the heart of Dallas, Texas. It's also the name of the book I will create when this journey is over. I think it sounds sweet.

How's this all going down?

I'm not affiliated with any organization. I'm just a dude who wants to do something good for my community. In order to do that, I've established a relationship with a local food bank who has provided me with contacts across the country and an inside look at what it takes to feed a city.

Over the next few months I will be making connections with food banks in major cities between Columbus and Dallas. I will depart on September 1 and plan to return home in early December. When I arrive in each city, I'll stay for 2 to 3 days to personally volunteer, meet the staff, and interview volunteers.

I'm beginning this journey on September 1 of this year, and the goal is to make it to Dallas in time for Thanksgiving. I'd like to be there to volunteer at a soup kitchen on Thanksgiving day.

After I complete my journey, I'll then fly home and begin the work of putting together a book that compiles all of the interviews and portraits of volunteers. Lucky for me, my roommate is a French Lit PhD and professor at OSU, and he will edit the writing so that the book is the best it can be. The end result will be a coffee table book full of illustrations and interviews that I hope will inspire others to volunteer in their own way. And the best thing of all is that half of the proceeds of the book will go directly to a local food bank here in central Ohio. It's a win/win.

Oh! And one last thing... Throughout the actual hike, I'll maintain a daily blog with photos and stories of the journey (blog site to be determined). This is a community endeavor, so I want to keep in touch with everyone involved.

Why hike to Texas?

A lot of people ask me this, and I have a few answers for those folks:

1. My story of hunger hit the hardest when I lived in Dallas in the summer of 2005. I think about those times often, so in a way it's a pilgrimage to where it all began for me.

2. I don't believe that anyone can fully sympathize with need unless they walk in it. To give the most honest account I possibly can, I will be living day to day out of my backpack for three months. It's not the easiest way to tell a story, but I believe that it's the most authentic way to connect with those in need and those who give.

3. The current discussion of hunger in this nation turns my stomach. I want to see every discussion about hunger involve reaching out to those in need, but unfortunately those aren't the stories that are most often told. I want to see the dialogue move from skepticism to compassion, and this type of project provides a platform to make voices heard. If walking halfway across the country creates buzz and elevates the discussion, then let's do this!

Where does the money go?

1. I'll need to buy more equipment to make the journey to Texas. I need a tent, all-weather clothing, boots, food, hotels for when I stop to volunteer in each city, and a plane ticket home.

2. I have a full-time job as an illustrator for a super awesome company, but I'll have to step away for a while to make this thing happen. By pledging above and beyond the 20k goal (please, please, please!), I'll be able to take a bit more time before heading back to work and make this the best art of my life. In short, the more you give, the more time I'll have to dedicate to make the best book possible (and your pledge perks!). A huge thanks in advance for this!

3. Last, but certainly not least, I believe that good work deserves to be fairly compensated. My wonderfully talented photographer and videographer has worked very hard to help me promote this project, and I refuse to ask for a discount for her services. So she gets a cut. I will also compensate my wicked-smart roommate for his editing prowess when the book is written. Again, good work deserves a good wage.

When do I receive my perks?

The very first thing to be sent out is the "Thank You" postcard. Those will be printed this summer and shipped by September 1. The rest of the art won't begin to be made until after I return home in December. Handmade art takes time, and that's why I've kept all of the custom pieces in short supply. I anticipate shipping finished art pieces from spring through summer 2016. The book will take longer to complete, and I am estimating closer to autumn or winter of 2016 before it's completed and printed. I will be sure to keep everyone posted with any updates as well as anticipated shipping dates.

What's up with all of the postcards?

When I think something is cool, I'm all about telling people about it. Postcards give an opportunity to create tangible pieces of art that can be send to friends and family all over the country. I want to get people talking about hunger and volunteering in a different way. This gives me (and you!) that kind of platform. Plus, postcards just look really cool!

I've never seen your art before, so what style can I expect?

I have a few images that will give you an idea of what your perks will look like.

"Thank You" Postcard:

This is a mockup of the image that ultimately become the "Thank You" postcard. The image will be redrawn over the next month to represent my more realistic style, but this gives you the direction of this particular piece.

Portraits:

I love black and white, and I love lines! When you see the lines in a person's face, you see a story that words can't tell. This mockup gives you an idea of what your portrait will look like, as well as the portrait postcards.


Chalkboards:

I've been very fortunate in my art career and it all started with chalkboards. I made this one for NHL player James Wisniewski. Everything I do is freehand, but I work very hard to make sure that everything is centered and consistent. No matter what you want on a chalkboard, I can recreate it. Bold colors, black and white, you name it. The only thing that I won't be able to do is blended colors (that takes traditional chalk, and that is something that I won't ship since it will smudge).


Here's another example of chalk work that I've done in Columbus. My work has been featured all over town in businesses large and small. Again, think bold lines and colors.


Reclaimed Wood Signs:

Here's an example of a hand painted storefront sign that I made out of reclaimed wood. I'll source the wood, stain it, build the board, paint your image, and finally coat the paint with an all-weather seal. Send me an image and I'll convert it into a nifty wooden sign like you see right here!

And there you have it! I've been told that my style is unique, I've been featured in several local publications for art pieces that I've done. You can expect the same level of dedication in your piece as I put into the work I do for biggest companies in town.

Thank You!

I'm so thankful for this life, and I want to give others that same hope while encouraging others to volunteer in their own communities. There's not a single step of this journey that has been solo. So a huge thank you for all who give to this project! Please share this with your friends and fight to see the dialogue of hunger change. I'll see you guys on the road!

There's not a single step of this journey that has been solo. So a huge thank you for all who give to this project! Please share this with your friends and fight to see the dialogue of hunger change. I'll see you guys on the road!

story:
The artist, who wants to do this project did hear from a Portugese friend about the Art-Deco cinema Odeon in Lisbon, did get funding to buy and renovate the cinema, which is standing empty since 1990, to prevend it from demolishing, to make place for a mall. The idea is to make a second Tuschinski-cinema project, like they did do in Amsterdam.

However contracts are signed, the original renovation costs, which was estimated on 1 million US Dollars, did raise to 3 million US Dollars, because formal owners did strip and demolish a lot of the original interior, because making place for a mall-design. Also during this period, several original Art- Deco artifacts, dating from 1930's, were stolen by thiefs for its metal materials.

The raise of renovation costs, means to make some main choices, what has to be restored, what the cinema needs to operate and stripe some decoration pieces, that has to be remade out of the planned budget, so the original funding can cover the costs.

The artist hopes through crowdfunding/ microinvestment to raise enough money, to be able to recreate the best decoration pieces, that were lost, but fall now out of the budget.

$1 a person does make already a whole difference. In the end, $1 from 17000 people is enough to help the end goal.

story:
Short Summary

This project is a unique collaboration between the arts and politics, with the aim raising funds to support Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender/Transsexual and Queer asylum seekers in the UK.

No Going Back began in 2012, providing free legal advice and representation for LGBTQ immigrants seeking asylum in the UK on the grounds they would be persecuted (and often put to death) in their home countries because of their sexual orientation.  With major cutbacks in legal aid, major language barriers typically faced by applicants and a judicial system often biased against claimants and seeking 'proof' of sexuality, NGB's mandate was grounded in ensuring that at least cost would not be a barrier for its clients, and that we would do whatever was in our power to advocate on their behalf and seek the justice they deserve.

Duality Books is publishing a monograph series, '1 Model & 100 Artists', the sales proceeds of which will go towards NGB's work with asylum seekers. 

To complement their bold work we will be holding an exhibition and auction in Leeds and possibly London for all original pieces going towards to the publication. 

We could use your help to really make this a successful, amazing event that both raises awareness and funds for a powerful and often overlooked cause!  Any and all funds raised would contribute to raising the exhibition(s) and covering any costs accruing from gallery hire, event promotions, framing, catering and transport of art work between depot and events sites as well as in sending costs (if required) to purchasers.  Hopefully, we can get as many donations as possible to increase the amount that can go back into our services, with raised funds making up the shortfall.

£2000 would enable us to host two events: one in Leeds, one in London.  If this is not reached then what is accrued will contribute still to all aspects of raising the exhibitions and the shortfall being accommodated by available organisational spend, including profits raised from auction.

Like with anything there are risks.  This project is no exception.  There is the possibility art works don't sell, either at all or in only small quantities.  Of the 100 artists contributing to the book possibly very few may donate their originals for sale, even though there has been a significant amount of interest to the contrary. Horror of horrors, a gallery space that has been donated (if only in part) may pull out!  These funds would enable us to mitigate many of these circumstance, especially the last one.  And though we cannot guess on the turnout to the events, or the financial outcome, we at least have secured free gallery space in Leeds that comes with equally free promotion, and in a venue - The White Cloth Gallery - known for its trendy atmosphere and cutting-edge exhibitions.

Any little helps!  Truly.  And any amount given here would incontrovertably save the lives of so many and enable just one more person to live freely and powerfully as who they are. 

So get the word out!  Feel free to contribute what you can, especially if you feel just as passionately about this cause.

For more on the '1 Model & 100 Artists' project visit: https://www.facebook.com/pages/1-Model-100-Artists/644345765661664?fref=ts.

For details on Duality Books and Simon O'Corra, the creative mastermind behind this project see: http://www.sachetmixte.com.

And to explore the work and commitment of No Going Back to LGBT asylum rights in the UK (or even look into working with us!) simply check us out at: http://nogoingback.org.uk.

For all general inquiries please contact Roy Butler at roy@nogoingback.org.uk.

story:
Short Summary

I'm an artist who is passionate about the beauty and wonder of animals, in particular the horse. This exhibition will showcase a few of my recent photos and paintings, themed around the wild spirit that the domestic horse retains. I would love to be able to share this with people during our "Wild Horse Day" at our shop, Sketched, Spun & Warped, located in Clunes, Victoria. This is a free event we are hosting as part of the Words in Winter Festival during August.

The funding will allow me to display my photos on large canvas prints, and to get my pastel paintings framed for the exhibition.

My friends and supporters tell me I have a unique vision to share through my art - I would love to be able to share it with more people.

story:
Short Summary

Greetings, my name is Jorge Lara and I am the Executive DIrector of The Las Vegas Poets Organization (www.lasvegaspoets.org) and Editor In Chief of VIM Magazine (www.vimmag.com). This past year our poetry organization celebrated 10 years of serving the Las Vegas community. Throughout this time our goal has been to promote the art of poetry in Las Vegas through initiatives and programs that reach out to local poets and the artistic community. In the past years we have worked with the Nevada Arts Council and Nevada Humanities to bring poetry to the Vegas Valley Book Festival and this past year we brought Pop-Up Poetry, our first poetry feature series with the help of Nevada Humanities. 



Since 2009 VIM Magazine (www.vimmag.com) has highlighted the artists and visionaries of Las Vegas and in 2015 the magazine will be going global as we spotlight artists from all over the US and the world in intimate interviews and photo shoots. Past VIM photographers have included: Shannon Dorn, Devon Ford, Frankie Darkstar, Chris Pittman, Salome Manska, and others.

Our work has been highlighted in:

http://lasvegas.cbslocal.com/top-lists/top-local-poets-in-las-vegas

http://www.lasvegasweekly.com/as-we-see-it/2008/sep/25/bringing-back-poetry

http://www.reviewjournal.com/view/downtown/poets-weave-fabric-local-literary-culture

http://www.desertcompanion.com/article.cfm?ArticleID=806

http://vegasseven.com/2010/05/13/whos-verse



We are now working on the next ten years of the organization and magazine and with your help we will broaden our goals and initiatives as we work to bring things to the next level.


What We Need & What You Get

For the first time in 10 years the Las Vegas Poets Organization is asking for your help. Your funding will help us to:

  • Continue our poetry organization website at www.lasvegaspoets.org and our official Meetup Organization group which is free to join and allows members to RSVP to local poetry readings, create a profile, post their events, and get emailed about all the latest happenings in the community.
  • Bring VIM Magazine to print and fund our photography retrospective exhibit that will feature select magazine photography from: Shannon Dorn, Frankie Darkstar, Chris Pittman, Devon Ford, Jorge Lara, and others. 
  • Launch the VIM Culture Show this year on Future Sound Radio on KUNV 91.5 fm. Future Sound Radio features that latest EDM music in Las Vegas and is hosted by Chad Martinez and Carey Cowart. The VIM Culture Show will be a 1o minute broadcast segment of Future Sound Radio that will highlight the weekly art and cultural scene in Vegas. (https://www.facebook.com/Futuresoundkunv)
  • Help bring the National Poetry Slam competitions to Las Vegas and assist local poetry Slam team Battleborn Slam as they represent Las Vegas at nationals.
  • Serve as a fiscal agent for other poetry groups and literary journals.
  • If our goal is not met any collected funds will go to help all our current programs and initiatives already in place. Please visit www.lasvegaspoets.org to learn more about our mission and history. 


The Impact

The Las Vegas Poets Organization, established in 2005 was created to help people discover Vegas poetry and promote the thriving poetry community. Working on the ideals and vision of Danna Nordin, past Las Vegas poet and resident who created a vision for the current poetry scene. With her inspiration the organization was created to bring unity to an artform that crosses and interwines with other artforms including music, theater, and art.  The organization was founded by local poet/artist Jorge Lara Santiago (www.immortalizer.net).

The organization has gone through various iterations throughout the years, having in the past established an executive and advisory board as well as having created a volunteer board. Past Executive Board members have included : Las Vegas teacher Rosa Mendoza (President), local poetry activist / zine archivist/ dj Jeffrey Bennington Grindley (President), Las Vegas musician/poet/poetry venue host R.J. Reynolds (Vice-President), poet/photographer Megan Milligan (secretary). 

Notable Advisory Board Members have included: Slam poet / activists Kari O'Connor and A.J. Moyer. As well as local luminaries / theatre actors Mundana Ess-haghabadi Ganir and Erik Amblad who with Born And Raised Productions helped The Las Vegas Poets Organization have their first fundraiser at the Green Valley Ranch Casino and were key in organizing the 18B Las Vegas Music Festival which prominently featured poetry in the Las Vegas arts district for two years.

Throughout the years the organization has been a vital resource of information and knowledge and has had a part in developing new local poetry venues that have included : Seldom Seen Poets at Sunrise Coffee,Human Experience at Emergency Arts, Painters and Poets at The Arts Factory, and Drink and Draw / Poetry at Blackbird Studios to name just a few.

For the past three years the organization has been fundamental in bringing poetry to the annual UNLV Festival Of Communities and with the participation of the Nevada Arts Council and Nevada Humanities has had the opportunity to prominently feature poetry at the Vegas Valley Book Festival and participate in the annual Nevada Poetry Out Loud.

In 2008, Las Vegas Poets Organization founder Jorge Lara created VIM Magazine, a local arts/humanities magazine that interviews local poets, artists, and visionaries. The magazine is now preparing to launch globally highlighting artists and visionaries from all over the world.

In the coming year the Las Vegas Poets Organization is working to serve a prominent role in bringing the art of Slam poetry to the forefront of individual minds in the community by working with the Battleborn Slam community, establish a downtown poetry series that will showcase established poets from Vegas past, and offer poetry workshops for up and coming poets who want to find their footing in their chosen art form of expression. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Add us on Facebook: 

http://www.facebook.com/lasvegaspoets

http://www.facebook.com/vimmag

Use the share tools on Indiegogo to help promote our campaign and thank you all for your continued support!
