story:
I am Kat Monroe, owner of Sev Ven art gallery  in  Huntington Beach, Ca.   In my years as a gallery owner, I have devoted my professional life to representing the work of hundreds of talented international and regional artists. I have enjoyed what every business owner longs for: dedicated, loyal and supportive clientele who keep coming back.

I am so proud of the business I have built and grateful to the artists and clients who choose to work with me. They are my inspiration every day, and I am now poised to celebrate their work in bigger and better ways. 

Sev Ven is an artist run gallery. Sev Ven’s mission is to exhibit and promote the work of talented artists and musicians from around the world, to provide artists and musicians with a gathering place for ideas, inspiration, collaborations opportunities ,and provide the public with an opportunity to see and learn about the artists and their work. At Sev Ven, we provide a venue for artists and musicians near and far to exhibit their work at minimum cost. Sev Ven is Sanctuary to a variety of artists, musicians and their creations. Sev Ven embraces a multitude of artistic ideas and mediums.

Sev Ven hosts monthly art openings, open to the public as well as monthly and weekly inspirational open studio events. 


THE CHALLENGE! THE GOAL!

The building where I have my gallery is no longer willing to extend my lease. I must move my entire operation and the work of my gifted artists and crafts professionals--among them Lou Rusconi, Mike Bell, Matthew Dutton, Al Benkin, PeeMonster, Ryan Myers, Jel Ena, Orlee Andromedae, Nic Caesar, Inge Vandormael, Amber Michelle Russell, Brett Hess, Ralski, Viva Venera, Vincent Gabriel, Paz, Shayne Bohner, to name a few. 

The good news: I am in the process of finding a suitable space for relocation,  But there remains much work to be done at significant expense. For the trust, confidence and community spirit of artists and patrons of Sev Ven, I am so very grateful!

Even better news: In support of "Let's Relocate the Gallery" many of my loyal gallery artists are enthusiastically contributing "incentive art" as perks to contributors at various levels. From a Lou Rusconi original painting to original art prints by a few talented artists and a New Years Eve gallery fundraiser and art cards by me -- along with many others -- these perks will delight you. Please take a look at what they have to offer!

You can help: Friends, neighbors, clients, other artists, business colleagues and others who are willing to pitch in to help offset the relocation costs and boost the future of Sev Ven  and its artists. There hardly isn't a donation level that doesn't include an art perk: check it out! 

My immediate costs include:

  •   Construction, lighting, painting and infrastructure improvements of a new location
  •   First and lasts months rent
  •   New lease deposit
  •   Moving costs and technology updates
  •   Advertising and marketing to support the launch at the new location 

It's my deepest wish that this campaign be NOT just about Sev Ven, but about its artists and their exceptional work. They are deserving of top-notch representation not just in their gallery owner, but in the gallery itself, and as we know, location means so much. 

Several remarkable people who have worked to help me launch the "Let's Relocate the Gallery Campaign" and I would like to recognize them and encourage any of you to connect with them professionally:

  • Jesse Sanchez: Photographer, videographer. 
  • Danaan McGregor: Artist and my right hand.
  • Nigel Metz: Web support at all levels
  • Dillon Hall: Artist, master of construction.
  • Ralski: Artist, graphic design.

Thank you in advance for your support and community spirit. Please make sure to stop by our new location when we announce our new address.



Artists Mike Bermudez and Vincent Gabriel.



Artists from near and far would get together at our Wed night Open Mic Music and Art Night.



Tom Dead Stuff, rear right.


Inside Sev Ven


Paz Art  triptych carving, left. Tom Deadstuff, right.



Artist Christina Anderson, Ms.Kat Monroe and Ralski


Surly Gurly at Sev Ven


Artist from all over the world send their art to Sev Ven to exhibit and sell. Many of these same artists have donated their time, creativity and art to help Sev Ven relocate.

Vince Packard, left. Little man created by Tim Ceja


Live painting by Steve Downs art Sev Ven Summer Art Kick Off at Sev Ven.

Summer Sev Ven Kick Off 2013


Artist Pinstripe Chris Dunlop adding beauty to a Harley at our Motorcycles, Cars and Guitars  Show.

Ice Sculpture at Sev Ven by The Ice Man of Huntington Beach at the Ice Store.


artist Steve Downs with his Live painting behind him, Sold at Sev Ven.

Matthew Dutton at Sev Ven.


Artists Ralski and Darcydoll Art

story:
Short Summary

Hi! We are an Edmonton based arts administration duo who have started a new arts based initiative called, CREATIVE PRACTICES INSTITUTE. Our two principals Connor & Brittney have been working in Alberta’s arts community for the past five years. We have experience in municipal government, public art galleries, artist run centres and as freelance creatives. We are opening a new studio rental, exhibition and alternative learning space within a character house in downtown Edmonton. We aim to become a hub for creatives to network and collaborate while opening up more dialogue between the art world and all others in Edmonton. As a startup with a non-profit model we are ineligible for most public funding until we have been operating for a year, as a result - we really need your help! Funds raised in this campaign are earmarked for artists fees and opening receptions.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $1000 

These funds will go towards paying artists fees to those artists who exhibit at CPI.

In return for sponsoring this project we offer a range of perks based on the amount pledged. Please see the right side of the site for details about the different tiers available.

If we do not meet our entire goal all the funds raised will go towards artist fees.

The Impact

It is very hard for emerging artists to make a living, many people ask artist to provide their services for free. By helping fund this project you are ensuring that at least seven artists will be paid for their time and energy. The opening reception serves as a networking and self promotion opportunity for our artists, they will have the chance to meet other artists, collectors, curators and other art professionals. As well there will be curatorial texts for each exhibition that the artist can utilize in their portfolio. We hope that our exhibitions will serve as a key stepping stone for our resident artists. Your contributions help to counter the stereotype of the starving artists. Help us show the local arts community of Edmonton that we value our young emerging artists!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if you are unable to support this campaign financially. We appreciate you taking the time to read about us. If you have a spare minute please make use of the Indiegogo share tools and help CREATIVE PRACTICES reach a wider audience! Also we are on facebook and twitter - like us via the icon's below :)

story:
What is RISE?

    Blessings Intelligent Souls, my name is Randell Adjei and I am the creator and founder of R.I.S.E Edutainment. RISE stands for Reaching Intelligent Souls Everywhere. What is now recognized as an arts and social consciousness movement, really started as an idea. The journey of RISE began two years ago on April 16th 2012 with the idea of bringing people together through the magic of the arts. 
       

     When RISE first started, I didn’t have any expectations of its longevity. I never had a long term plan. All I knew was all I had to do was put love into it. So I did. The first RISE Poetry show, there was a little over 20 people in a small community space inside Scarborough Town Centre. Every Monday, somehow, more people came to share their voice. As the weeks turned into months, the number of youth doubled. Yet, every single week the level of talent within our community continued to surprise me. 

     Four weeks into RISE, I met Anthony, an up and coming photographer. We connected instantly. Since we’ve met, he and I have worked closely to build RISE into a movement. We’ve worked together to build:

1) RISE Poetry Monday
      RISE Poetry is the backbone of RISE Edutainment. Through RISE Poetry, we’ve helped provide a space for more than a thousand youth to creatively express themselves in a positive space and build innovative leaderships skills. At the end of every month, emerging artists get to interact and hear first-hand
from professional artist during RISE’S Alchemy, Benevolence and Culture panel
discussions. RISE Poetry is a place where people come knowing they will be accepted. Where people come to create and share, and most importantly, to love and be loved. The teachings of self-love and the deconstructing of the word ‘impossible’ allows artists to believe in their infinite potential.

2) Edutainment Convention
       Last year, we worked on the first annual Edutainment Convention which was a weekend filled with workshops at the North York Civic Centre and performances at the Toronto Centre of the Arts. The main purpose of the Edutainment Convention is to bridge the gap between upcoming artists and professional artists. Most importantly, we aim to Edutain: educate others through entertainment.

3) 416RISE

       416RISE is the anniversary celebration of RISE. The numerology of our start date happens to coincide with the area code of our city of Toronto. This year we had an arts enrichment panel with highly respected community leaders such as Giancarlo "Lo"Falcioni Dean of the business academy at The Remix Project, Dwayne Dixon Executive Director of Manifesto, Sabra Ripley City of Toronto Culture Arts Services Management Staff, Michael Prosserman Founder of Unity Charity and will be moderated by Amy Hosotsuji of GYC Toronto. And featured performances from international artivists, D’bi Young & Maestro Fresh Wes and local talents.

4) Artist Development and Workshops

       Together we’ve gone to elementary schools and high schools to teach students how to dig deep within their hearts, build the courage to translate their feelings on paper, and confidently share it with their peers and others.

 

What is YEMOYA?

YEMOYA is a three week international artist residency, developed by D’bi that combines trans-disciplinary arts training with wellness practices for the (w)holistic development of people. Founded in summer 2008 in Toronto Canada, YEMOYA’s intensive twenty-one day program focuses on the creative, physical, mental, emotional and spiritual growth and development of its resident artists, using the Sorplusi Method. YEMOYA alumni include international artists such as Ngozi Paul, Kemba King, Titilope Sonuga, Jamilah Malika, Ria Hartley, Che Kothari, Bahia Watson, Mriga Kapadiya, LInda Kaoma, Amanda Parris, Adiyana Morris, Liza Paul, Julene Robinson, Raphael Cohen, Lishai Peel, Colanthony Humphreys, Kalmplex, Erin Bosenberg, Webster McDonald and Geordie Gescha. Residencies have been hosted in Canada, England, South Africa, Belize, Jamaica and The Bahamas.

Why is it important for us to attend this residency program?

Our art is our passion. We live through it. Now, we strongly desire to grow as individuals, as artists, and most importantly artivists. We want to be able to influence, inspire and uplift the world through the power of our art. YEMOYA will help us develop our artistic skills so that we can not only sustain ourselves as full time artist, but also stretch our influence beyond the city of Toronto. We want to inspire as many intelligent souls as possible. We’re thinking big… to prove that there is no such thing as “I can’t”.

What We Need & What You Get

 The fact of the matter is that both Anthony and myself don't have the funds to cover the flight and the residency program itself.

Therefore All funds raised will go towards the following:

1. Our return flight to Hawaii!  2. The residency program!  3. Food! 

In return for the generous people who can afford to support us, we are offering  Original signed prints from the world renowned photographer Che Kothari. One on one workshops with the founder of the YEMOYA program and the award winning international dub poet D'bi Young. We are also offering one on one workshops with Lishai Peel and myself. Lastly you can get your own personal shoot with Anthony if you're in need of some photos!

Can't Help Financially? Other Ways to Support

We totally understand that not everyone is in a financial position to help in the way that they would like to. So, we ask instead to share our campaign and let people know about the change we will make through art and love. We extend our hearts with gratitude and appreciation for your time and support! We love all of you, intelligent souls.

Blessings from Randell and Anthony

www.twitter.com/RisePoetry

www.instagram.com/xvxyphoto

“The best way to find your self is to
lose yourself in the service of others”.

story:
The idea for the Positive Shop came to us in April 2015 when our decision for change moved us towards leaving behind our more or less comfortable jobs and start living a simple life close to nature. Motivated and once exited from that change we started to spread the message of positivity by “putting it into a frame”

We rented an old, abandoned place and with in a month the doors of the Positive Shop were opened! From the begining we received a very warm reaction from all our visitors, that with their kind words encouraged us to continue. The process wasn't easy,with out funds and only with our personal work we let our inner child improvise and to create

Inspired by several mediums, we created Hand Painted Quote Signs, Art Compositions made from natural materials and creations based on Photography using various techniques.
 

We also organized activities:

The book exchange department with titles on psychology, philosophy and self development from our personal collection and from donations which hopefully will grow to a free lending library. 

Three themed exhibitions based on Movies, Animals and Music that are meeting points for people with similar interests.

We made mistakes: technical, spelling mistakes, wrong cooperation, mistakes that caused accidents and mistakes on projects we don't even want to remember! We continued not because we avoided mistakes,but because we learned from them and moved on.

                              Our future plans include:  

    We feel ready to push the "Book Sharing" section idea a step further turning it into a beautifully organized "Free Positive Lending Library" with more or less of 500 book titles  in various languages. It will be accompanied with a terrain map designed by us, including many different nature trails, local routes, and "hidden" locations to explore and settle down to read.

Perhaps, in our times, knowledge can be transferred faster through the means of technology. Even so, turning the pages of a book, remains a unique experience and personal journey. The intimate touch and feeling which transcends through reading a book, can hardly be replaced. 

To complete the Positive Lending Library project we need:

*The supplies to work on our wooden book "shape" self design that we will hand craft and paint.

*Get & Categorize a 300+ book title collection

 *Move the "Map project" to production

A calendar that ignores days and can be used forever!

Separated in three editions (People - Moments – Animals) based on high resolution photographs with quotes that can become slogans each and every month this calendar will remind you to behold a positive stance or at least put a smile in your face!

 

(See demo preview of the Calendar project in better quality at the end of the story)

We have completed all three calendar Cover- Inner &  Box designs, to continue & complete this project we will need:

*Supplies to handcraft the wooden box design

*Move Cover & Inner designs to Print production

"Drawgital" is the word we came up when we start putting together hand sketched pencil drawings with a Digital Re-Touch

All this time we've been creating drawgital art and now we need to move this project to production by printing these high resolution designs on Canvas.

We have invested in these projects and their actualization is necessary for the survival of the Positive Shop. 

The two of us made it here.

We gave a part of our lives to make this idea come to life. It’s difficult for us to think that everything can end so suddenly while our vision and planning is at its peak.

Financial difficulties and a car accident that left us without a vehicle for the last two years kept us back on the new projects and left us with a dept on fixed expenses.

Our mood is still pleasant, Positivity is about dealing with anything that comes your way!

We don't put our heads down! The Positive Shop lives primarily in our heart and mind, we believe that our ideas are worth coming to Reality.

As visionaries, dreamers and lovers of art we proved that if you can dream something you can also make it real.

With your contribution and  support to raise the necessary funds so will be able to continue doing what we love with the same passion.This place changed our lives and has spread smiles and nice memories around. We will do our best for it to continue to exist. Everyone can get involved in the Positive campaign, either you wish to contribute, with a donation or sharing the word on social media and friends, your support is precious and means a lot to us!

Whatever the outcome might be, we feel blessed for getting the chance to share our thoughts and ideas with all of you!

Thank you for your time and your participation to our effort in any way you can.

Lot's of love! Stay Positive!

With much appreciation, Billy & Smaragdi

 

 

Calendar project image preview

Hand Drawing Hippocrates

Drawgital Albert Einstein

story:
'Young, Broke And About To Become Homeless'; the reasons behind the #kissmeonelasttime #washableart campaign!

It was a rainy December evening. I was walking home from Birkbeck, the university in London where I studied Theatre and Drama. The Tories had just announced that grants for low-income students were being cut for good and the Arts Council of England had just experienced another blow to their funding and started to encourage artists to turn into a money-making, self-funding commercial profit makers. If there was a future, it was not looking bright and shiny.

I was in my final year working on my dissertation, had two part-time jobs and could barely make ends meet when my landlord left an eviction note outside my room.

The timing couldn't have been better; I had just had a lecture on Protesting, Politics and Theatricality. We discussed all the ways in which politics is being performed and structured for the media, marching is being restricted, and people get kettled in by police to create false headlines for the press. Of course, the cherry on top was that if you wanted to organise a protest you had to ask permission first.

I wanted to cry and scream at the same time but knew that it wouldn't get me anywhere. I was frustrated and angry, my blood was boiling, and I was furiously pacing around Euston. Could I speak up? Who would listen to me and what could I do to stop and improve this political and economic grey madness which seemed to lurk at every possible angle? What do you do when you have no control over your housing situation, theatres and community centres are closing down, and there is nothing you can do to stop gentrification and social cleansing because you are part of it?

And I wanted to shout; I wanted to speak up, protect what’s dear to me and to you, to everyday people. So I marched into The Lamb, the pub where I used to work part-time and said to the first person I saw, who happened to be my colleague, also an actor, Wuzza, 'how do you feel about making graffiti?' 'Graffiti?' ‘Yes! Washable graffiti, a political message across London, interacting with the city. Places are being forced to close down because they can't afford to pay new, increased rent, people are being relocated from one side of London to the other, social cleansing and gentrification is destroying London as we know it, and it’s happening at lightning speed! Shall we celebrate what we have before it’s gone forever? It might be messy and we might get into trouble.' Without hesitation, he said ‘Let’s do this. When, now?’ ‘Yes, now.'

And that’s how the idea of washable art was born. Our performance will be documented and showcased as a sweet remembrance of times we had.

Lots of love,
Elina and Wuzza

story: This year the Advanced Diploma of Graphic Design students are holding an end of year exhibition called, "Keep It Brief". This will showcase all our work over the past 6 months, where we started and where we are now. Any donation will be greatly appreciated and will go to making this event possible. We hope to see you there.

story:
In 2011, I opened an art space called Aviary in Jamaica Plain, MA. After nine years of regular bi-monthly exhibitions, over 100 music shows, dozens of workshops, and countless other events (including a wedding!), Aviary will transition to an online exhibition space after our lease ends in December. With the pandemic being a nightmare and rent increases in Jamaica Plain being also a nightmare, we just can't afford to sign a third five-year lease.

I've always thought that the beautiful building at 708 West Rosemary Street in Carrboro, North Carolina would be a perfect art space. It became available this summer and due in part to the generosity of my new landlord (a supporter of the arts), I was able to sign the lease and decided to open Peel. 

 

WHAT IS PEEL?

Peel is an art gallery, community event space, digital photography lab, and retail space promoting contemporary art. We are dedicated to supporting the work of emerging, mid-career, and under-recognized artists through diverse and unique educational programming.

Peel is intended to go beyond the model of traditional exhibition space, to offer a curated selection of local art, photography, jewelry, books, comics, and zines in addition to monthly gallery exhibitions. After gallery hours, the space will host workshops, lectures, concerts, film screenings, and music performances.

 

HOW WILL THIS SPACE BENEFIT/IMPACT THE COMMUNITY?

As an integrated art, education, retail, and event space, Peel seeks to create a dynamic model that promotes accessibility, inspires creativity, and enables/empowers the whole community through a diversity of use and programming.

 

PEEL WILL

  • Serve and represent the whole community through an emphasis on including works by artists marginalized as a result of their sexuality, ethnicity, gender, disability, class-status, formal educational level, or immigration status.
  • Provide space for local photographers to make, scan, and print their own work.
  • Furnish artists with a place to meet, share their work, attend workshops, and have their work photographed.
  • Lift up Carrboro’s independent arts scene while exciting and empowering collaboration towards more equitable community growth, through conversation and community-centered programming, residencies, and artist-led outreach.
  • Present streaming art talks, lectures, and screenings via the gallery’s website for accessibility and wider reach of eyes and ears.
  • Offer development opportunities for emerging and student artists and curators, especially PoC, to increase representation and access to resources, grants, press, collectors, fellowships, internships, and mentorship.
  • Make available space for the community to use for public and private events.

 

WHY WE NEED YOU RIGHT NOW

I’m writing to ask you to be involved with the creation of Carrboro’s newest and North Carolina’s only art gallery, digital photography lab, and community event space. Startup expenses are looking to be between $24,326 and $36,275 dollars at the moment. Our reach goal is $59,895 which would cover opening costs and provide the first six months of rent plus bills. Funds raised will allow us to start our business with financial integrity so we may open and grow in spite of the pandemic. Please join us in supporting art and artists.

Thank you SO much for your support and for reading all of these words.  Get in touch if you have any questions or would like to help open Peel and make it a meaningful, sustainable part of our community. For other ways to get involved go to www.peel.gallery. 

 

Please stay safe and well and don’t forget to vote!

 

Sincerely,

Lindsay Metivier
story_txt:
In 2011, I opened an art space called Aviary in Jamaica Plain, MA. After nine years of regular bi-monthly exhibitions, over 100 music shows, dozens of workshops, and countless other events (including a wedding!), Aviary will transition to an online exhibition space after our lease ends in December. With the pandemic being a nightmare and rent increases in Jamaica Plain being also a nightmare, we just can't afford to sign a third five-year lease.I've always thought that the beautiful building at 708 West Rosemary Street in Carrboro, North Carolina would be a perfect art space. It became available this summer and due in part to the generosity of my new landlord (a supporter of the arts), I was able to sign the lease and decided to open Peel.  WHAT IS PEEL?Peel is an art gallery, community event space, digital photography lab, and retail space promoting contemporary art. We are dedicated to supporting the work of emerging, mid-career, and under-recognized artists through diverse and unique educational programming.Peel is intended to go beyond the model of traditional exhibition space, to offer a curated selection of local art, photography, jewelry, books, comics, and zines in addition to monthly gallery exhibitions. After gallery hours, the space will host workshops, lectures, concerts, film screenings, and music performances. HOW WILL THIS SPACE BENEFIT/IMPACT THE COMMUNITY?As an integrated art, education, retail, and event space, Peel seeks to create a dynamic model that promotes accessibility, inspires creativity, and enables/empowers the whole community through a diversity of use and programming. PEEL WILL
Serve and represent the whole community through an emphasis on including works by artists marginalized as a result of their sexuality, ethnicity, gender, disability, class-status, formal educational level, or immigration status.
Provide space for local photographers to make, scan, and print their own work.
Furnish artists with a place to meet, share their work, attend workshops, and have their work photographed.
Lift up Carrboro’s independent arts scene while exciting and empowering collaboration towards more equitable community growth, through conversation and community-centered programming, residencies, and artist-led outreach.
Present streaming art talks, lectures, and screenings via the gallery’s website for accessibility and wider reach of eyes and ears.
Offer development opportunities for emerging and student artists and curators, especially PoC, to increase representation and access to resources, grants, press, collectors, fellowships, internships, and mentorship.
Make available space for the community to use for public and private events.
 WHY WE NEED YOU RIGHT NOWI’m writing to ask you to be involved with the creation of Carrboro’s newest and North Carolina’s only art gallery, digital photography lab, and community event space. Startup expenses are looking to be between $24,326 and $36,275 dollars at the moment. Our reach goal is $59,895 which would cover opening costs and provide the first six months of rent plus bills. Funds raised will allow us to start our business with financial integrity so we may open and grow in spite of the pandemic. Please join us in supporting art and artists.Thank you SO much for your support and for reading all of these words.  Get in touch if you have any questions or would like to help open Peel and make it a meaningful, sustainable part of our community. For other ways to get involved go to www.peel.gallery.  Please stay safe and well and don’t forget to vote! Sincerely,Lindsay Metivier

story:
UPDATE:

Ephemeral Garden Ready to Print!

THANK YOU so much for your support! I've finished the design, and the book is currently being printed. At 102 pages, the book has more than doubled in size from what I originally anticipated. Designing and editing this book has been one of the most challenging things I've done as an artist. I'm really pleased with the result, and I'm so excited to share it with you!

Because the book length has grown so much, the printing cost for 100 copies has grown as well (from $2,500 to $3,421). If you'd like to order additional copies, make a donation, or share my campaign with friends I'd be most grateful! 

Wishing you all the best... 

Jenine

Ephemeral Garden is an art book featuring photographs of stunning and dreamlike floral installations created during an artist residency in France last Spring.

The specs:

  • 10x8” hardcover
  • 102 pages
  • Over 60 full-color plates rendered on premium matte paper
  • Limited first edition of 100 copies signed by the artist
  • Featuring an essay (French/ English) by Didier Rousseau-Navarre, sculptor and founder of Jardin Botanique in Marnay-sur-Seine, France
  • Article (Dutch/ English) by Elisabeth van Sandick from Paradijsvogels Magazine

More images at:

www.jenineshereos.com

www.thisiscolossal.com

www.paradijsvogelsmagazine.nl

 

Portrait of the artist by Abril M Barrueccos

Artist Biography:

Jenine Shereos is an American artist who uses textile techniques alongside natural and organic materials to explore the complex and tenuous relationship between humans and the natural world. While her oeuvre includes installation, photography and sculptural works, she is best known for her intricately crafted leaves stitched entirely with human hair. 

The work of Jenine Shereos has been exhibited widely both nationally and internationally and included in exhibitions at Centraal Museum in Utrecht, Netherlands; Musée Jean Lurçat et de la tapisserie contemporaine in Angers, France; Museo dell'Arte Fabbrile e delle Coltellerie in Maniago, Italy; Muzeum Miasta Gdyni in Gdynia, Poland; The Montreal Center for Contemporary Textiles in Montreal, Canada; and Long Beach Museum of Art in Long Beach, California. Her work has also been featured in The Los Angeles Times, The Boston Globe, Frame Magazine, and Mary Schoeser’s publication; Textiles: The Art of Mankind. 

Jenine Shereos is a recipient of the Massachusetts Cultural Council Fellowship in Crafts, and The Rogers Fellowship for Textile Arts at The Hambidge Center in Rabun Gap, Georgia. She is currently a Visiting Lecturer in the Fibers Department at Massachusetts College of Art and Design in Boston, Massachusetts.

story:
Medusa Madness is a Burning Man art installation chosen to be featured at the prestigious Center Camp location. We have been given a partial grant to fund this amazing project and we need your help to put on the greatest fire show on earth.....Ok, the Playa. Each of the 25 snakes protruding from Medusa's head will blow fire at the rate of 100 gallons of propane an hour!
Medusa's face is made of mirrored stainless steel and stands 14' tall by 11' wide. The snakes reach a height of 27' and a distance of approximately 60'. The participants lucky enough to avoid Medusa's stone inducing stare can take shelter from the Playa heat under the canopy of her skullcap.
At night the snakes will not only come alive from the fire they breath but they will be illuminated with a massive number of addressable LED lights.
All of this awesomeness takes a lot of money and we need your help to complete this project. Please give what you can. We really appreciate it.

story:
Larry Holland of Fishbone Art and organizer of Secret Doors Decatur, with the support of the Decatur Arts Alliance and the Decatur Downtown Development Authority, is back at it with a new public art initiative: the Decatur Box Project. You may have seen the handful of traffic signal boxes at intersections around town that have been transformed from their drab, gray and corroded metal into colorful, whimsical works of art. What a fun addition to Decatur's outdoor gallery!

Larry is coordinating the project on a bigger scale now and plans to recruit some of the metro area’s top local artists to embellish up to twenty more boxes around Decatur. The installation is expected to be complete by late September 2016. 

The Decatur Arts Alliance and the Decatur Downtown Development Authority have generously granted this project $1500, but the estimated cost of providing artists with a stipend for materials and modest compensation for their time is at least $4000. Several local businesses, including Leon’s Full Service, Brick Store Pub, the Kimball House, and more, have enthusiastically agreed to sponsor the project, but the goal can be met much faster with community involvement.

Please help make the Decatur Box Project a reality soon by offering a contribution of *any amount* to the fund (sponsorship levels to the right are only a suggestion), with the aim of raising at least $2000. The more funds raised, the more boxes can be commissioned. Your donation will support local artists while funding an initiative that livens up the streetscape to be appreciated by all. It’s this kind of creativity that makes our city such a fun and unique place to live. Let's continue to make Decatur a leading public arts destination!

story:
Short Summary

In the fourth issue of UQ we want to analyse various concepts relating to intimacy. Through discussions and sharing of interests, we quickly discovered that we all have a preoccupation with reading diaries, letters, interviews and poetry that revolve around the personal and emotional text. With this issue we want to create a space that explores how private content can be presented for mass audience and in turn what happens to that content once it is available to the public realm. 

Our goal is to create a publication that is focused, accessible, engaging and visually stimulating. The publication aims to be personal and collective; it is as much about creating ongoing relationships and conversations, as it is about the collaborative interpretation of intimacy.

    The Impact

    In the openness of digital culture, we share our personal lives on public platforms, which results in a shift in the way we are intimate with thoughts, people and objects. We started by researching the questions: what is intimacy? and what can intimacy mean today? We discovered that it can be experienced emotionally, physically, intellectually, spiritually, individually, collectively and beyond. As intimacy is such an abstract and subjective concept, we want to open up the term to different interpretations.

    Challenging the conventions of a publication, there will not only be a compilation of creative works inspired by intimacy and its interpretations from a range of contributors but also a day-long event. The production of the text and its content will have equal weight in our publication. The act of choosing and reframing is a story in itself. This opening up to interpretation provides opportunities for internal contributions from the team and external commissions from artists, writers and practitioners.

    What We Need & What Your Support Means

    Your funding will be for commissioning texts and images for the publication and gratuity for invited collaborators which include artists, practitioners, and poets from various fields. They will share their perspectives by leading readings, workshops, and talks to generate new possibilities when thinking about and experiencing intimacy today. The event will take place on 4 September and will be open for the public to participate.

    Funding needed:

    • We aim to provide honorarium to commissioned writers, poets, artists and event collaborators

    The project is based on intensive collaboration and group work. As aspiring curators, writers, and designers, we are using this publication to reflect on our own development. It is an opportunity to work on skills and practices that are important to us, and also ones we haven't yet encountered. As a funder, you are providing support to a group of students interested in critically reflecting upon practices when generating and presenting creative and cultural knowledge.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Come participate at our event on 4th Sept! Interested participants will be required to express their interest by sending their name and email to uq.unknownquantities@gmail.com by the 31st of August 2016. To facilitate a fair selection process in case we receive more than 40 registrations, participants will be randomly selected. 

    Contribute texts, images, or an intervention to the publication! Interested participants will be required to express their interest by sending their name, email, and portfolio to uq.unknownquantities@gmail.com by the 4th Sept 2016.

    Spread the word and help us distribute! The final publication is due to be published in Dec 2016, and will be available for sale. We are open to receiving distribution support.

story:
Master Bed Vroom

We are creating this art car to bring joy and happiness to festival goers this summer at Burningman related North West regional burner events!

This project is important because it will make space for people to meet and exchange in a beautiful comfortable environment, and form lasting memories. It will allow us to contribute by creating space for others to magnify their experience and enjoyment of these events.

Your contributions will facilitate the design, construction, and logistics of this whimsical project.

Funding

We are trying to raise $7500. This will cover the following:

  • Purchase of the stretched golf cart
  • Cost of rebuilding the engine and new parts for increased reliability and safety
  • Steel, wood, fasteners, fabrics, paint and construction and welding supplies for the frame work, body, and general artistic and functional modifications
  • LED lighting to create a disco ceiling on the underside of the canopy and four LED lanterns for night lighting
  • Electrical parts, wiring, battery, and inverter
  • Propane piping, valves, fittings, tanks and parts for the flame effects
  • On board sound system
  • Logistical costs including trailer rental, ferries, extra fuel and oil
We are trying to pack a lot of amazing features into a small package and with your help we will succeed!

Contest! Burningman Ticket!

For every $5 you donate, your name will be put into a draw for a 2014 Burningman Ticket (ex. $20, four chances)!  We will video the draw and post the video on our facebook page announcing the winner.

See you on the Playa!

Master Bed Vroom is our way of bringing joy and enhanced experiences to participants at Otherworld, and Burn in the Forest this year. Please help us create this lighthearted yet powerful contribution to the festival art landscape.

Participate.

Please visit our facebook page if you would like to participate in the creation or contribute in any other way. Thank you so much!

http://www.facebook.com/MasterBedVroom


Picture shown is an artist's concept, actual Master Bed Vroom to be even more amazing and excellent. Image production credit: Gregory Hass

story:
Cross Your Art Wood Prints

     We are a husband and wife team that combined our talents, one day, and came up with something new. We crossed our photography with wood and pyrography. We decided that we would present it to the world through the humble vendor markets found at events and festivals. Being also students at our local community college, parents to our three awesome kids, and employees to our part-time jobs, it has been quite the process to put our ideas into a business. We aimed to do so because we wanted to share our unique art with the world, as well as let our talents work for us. What it has become, however, is so much more than that. It is a solution to our problems that stemmed from the recession. It's our means to provide for our family, without sacrificing anymore quality time. It's allowing us to travel, as well as expose our children to art, music, other cultures and communities. This is our opportunity to shine the light on the beauty we have found in this life.

We have put forth everything we have just to get started, and we are almost ready! We still need a vehicle capable of transporting our art, equipment, and supplies to and from these events and festivals that we plan to vend at. Between a Toyota Sienna and a Honda Odyssey, we can get a good used vehicle for $5000. This will cover the purchase, insurance, registration, and any necessary maintenance. To reach this goal, we'd like to begin "pre-selling" our art. Take a look at the perks listed on the right. We have several different contribution packages to choose from that we will hand create, just for you. All art pieces will be made from scratch; we will not be using pre-made art to pre-sell to you. Choose a photo from below that you want on your piece, per the perk you choose. Tell us your choice when you make your order, and leave the rest up to us! We are certain you will enjoy our creations just as much as we do! In the event that we over-reach our goal, we will use all excess funds to to replenish supplies (like ink and finish), maintain or upgrade our tools and equipment, as well as use it for vending fees for upcoming events.

If you'd like to help, but can't, you can still help us by telling your family, friends, and co-workers about Cross Your Art Wood Prints. Use the indiegogo share tools to inspire everyone you know. Let them know about our campaign, and also visit our website/online store:

festivalnet.com/crossyourartwoodprints

It's in it's infancy, but is about to hit a growth spurt, so keep coming back to see what is new! Also, you can contact us by email at:

    crossyourartwoodprints@yahoo.com

Thank you for your help!

story:
We've reached our crowdfunding goal! YAY! We are so grateful to all those who've helped to make this possible! But we also see that people keep donating and that's great, because the more money we get the more beautiful we can print the Reality Tickets, work on details, enhance the experience etc. etc., basically just make sure this will turn out to be as good as possible. Big Hug to you all.

All realities are real, but some are more real than others.

 

 

In the 19th century we filled in the last blank spots of our planet. No more Unknown Territories to discover. Our entire planet has been mapped and documented, and moreover by 2020 even the last remote spot on our planet might be connected to the Internet. Gone are the days of heroic adventures into the Unknown.

However, in recent years a new Unknown Territory suddenly appeared again on our planet: The World of Virtual Reality. We will embark on a Mission to explore this new world, and will do so in the Black Rock Desert of Nevada during the Burning Man Festival.

A Turing Test for Reality

At Burning Man 2017 a small crew of artists will be locked up inside a black box for the entire week of the festival. They will never leave the box, and won't ever see what's happening outside.

With their art they will create a virtual Burning Man on the inside walls without ever viewing the outside, just based on what visitors tell them. Through the duration of the festival, the inside walls of the construction will be continuously filled with the collaborative Crew /Visitors’ interpretation of the outside reality.

 

The Visitors wear VR goggles, their bridge between reality and virtuality. But where does their reality end and virtuality begin? Is what they see ‘real’? And how will they know the difference?

The entire project Is captured with a professional stereoscopic 360 rig and edited into an immersive VR experience of their mission at Burning Man.

The resident Crew will stay inside the Monolith during the entire course of the event, but they will still have some form of outside presence: for each of the Crewmembers physical “Avatars” will be created. These avatars, outfitted with a mini-360-camera, will roam the Playa. They will be life-size photos mounted on wood, which will be carried around by Burners and can be interacted with in the desert. 2D and 360-degree pictures and clips taken with the Avatars will be send back to the Monolith. Their journey and experience becomes part of the overall story.

Upon leaving visitors will receive a colorful beautifully printed entrance ticket - ‘Reality - Admit One’ - to the outside world/default Reality. The back of the entrance ticket will act as a kind of ‘terms and conditions’ featuring thoughts and insights on (Virtual) Reality.

The departure for the mission and homecoming of our crew will both be special ritual moments. After all, Reality won’t be the same anymore after this transformative journey. What will be their perception of “real” reality after they land again?

 

Philosophy

The actual definition of “reality” has been a universal question for ages. In today’s world with the current generation of Virtual Reality technology the definition of Reality is stretched even more, and boundaries between realities have become even more blurred.

Solipmission asks that old universal question again: “What is Reality?” With this project we explore this question with tools that previously belonged to the realm of science fiction. We are creating a bridge allowing visitors to cross over from science fiction into reality. But then again: How real is Reality?

Realizing the value(s) of both our human, real reality and digital, technological reality might enable a smoother transition into a future world, which will see a symbiosis of both.

Physical description

The project will be located inside a 25 x 25 x 25 feet black box. A black monolith, adorned with the colorful Solipmission logo, with a small door beneath it.

Inside the box there will be an inner cylinder of 18 feet in diameter with 12 feet high walls and a smaller fenced off circle for the visitors, with a VR-camera installed in the centre of the construction. Visitors will enter and leave through a small ante chamber. The inside of the Monolith will be illuminated with both indirect natural light, as well as additional neutral lighting.

Personnel will wear special overalls with our logo. Room for storage, sleeping, portapotties etc will be placed between the outside walls of cylinder and the inner wall of the box.

In science a black box is an object, which can be viewed in terms of input/output interactions with no knowledge of its internal workings. In Islam the Kaa’bah, the most holy object, has the form of a black box. In Space Odyssey 2001 black monoliths trigger transitions in human evolution. It thus symbolically links the scientific, spiritual, and human project aspects.

Past Burning Man Projects

In 2002 we built a big wooden threemaster in Amsterdam - the Fools Ark - which was shipped to the States, and then burnt in the desert.

In 2003 one hundred and forty paper maché Greymen surrounded an altar in the desert. People could customize those Greymen during the week, and at the end of the event burn their own inner Greyman during 140 private rituals.

In 2008 we protected the border between Dreams and Reality with the Department of Dreamland Security at Checkpoint Dreamyourtopia - a border control checkpoint to enter your own Dreams. A year later we tore down the walls between Dreams and Reality in an old swimming pool in Berlin with chainsaws and sledgehammers, exactly twenty years after the Berlin Wall fell.

In 2011 people could sign a Spiritual Karma Laundering contract at the Exchanghibition Bank. That would bring their spiritual Karma debt back to Zero, and in return they'd get a Zero banknote.

In 2012 the Exchanghibition Banknotes were hanging as leaves from the branches of the Transformoney Tree. People could draw and paint on real banknotes, turning their Money into Art, and then glue those banknotes onto the tree.

In 2013 we guided people on their Spiritual Path to Enlikement with Like4Real.

 

Epilogue

Reality still has more pixels than the screen of your iPhone. But even if in the future Virtual Reality will have more pixels than Reality itself, will that make VR more realistic than Reality?
story_txt:
We've reached our crowdfunding goal! YAY! We are so grateful to all those who've helped to make this possible! But we also see that people keep donating and that's great, because the more money we get the more beautiful we can print the Reality Tickets, work on details, enhance the experience etc. etc., basically just make sure this will turn out to be as good as possible. Big Hug to you all.All realities are real, but some are more real than others. 

 
 In the 19th century we filled in the last blank spots of our planet. No more Unknown Territories to discover. Our entire planet has been mapped and documented, and moreover by 2020 even the last remote spot on our planet might be connected to the Internet. Gone are the days of heroic adventures into the Unknown.However, in recent years a new Unknown Territory suddenly appeared again on our planet: The World of Virtual Reality. We will embark on a Mission to explore this new world, and will do so in the Black Rock Desert of Nevada during the Burning Man Festival.A Turing Test for RealityAt Burning Man 2017 a small crew of artists will be locked up inside a black box for the entire week of the festival. They will never leave the box, and won't ever see what's happening outside.With their art they will create a virtual Burning Man on the inside walls without ever viewing the outside, just based on what visitors tell them. Through the duration of the festival, the inside walls of the construction will be continuously filled with the collaborative Crew /Visitors’ interpretation of the outside reality. The Visitors wear VR goggles, their bridge between reality and virtuality. But where does their reality end and virtuality begin? Is what they see ‘real’? And how will they know the difference?The entire project Is captured with a professional stereoscopic 360 rig and edited into an immersive VR experience of their mission at Burning Man.The resident Crew will stay inside the Monolith during the entire course of the event, but they will still have some form of outside presence: for each of the Crewmembers physical “Avatars” will be created. These avatars, outfitted with a mini-360-camera, will roam the Playa. They will be life-size photos mounted on wood, which will be carried around by Burners and can be interacted with in the desert. 2D and 360-degree pictures and clips taken with the Avatars will be send back to the Monolith. Their journey and experience becomes part of the overall story.Upon leaving visitors will receive a colorful beautifully printed entrance ticket - ‘Reality - Admit One’ - to the outside world/default Reality. In Islam the Kaa’bah, the most holy object, has the form of a black box. In Space Odyssey 2001 black monoliths trigger transitions in human evolution. It thus symbolically links the scientific, spiritual, and human project aspects.Past Burning Man ProjectsIn 2002 we built a big wooden threemaster in Amsterdam - the Fools Ark - which was shipped to the States, and then burnt in the desert.In 2003 one hundred and forty paper maché Greymen surrounded an altar in the desert. People could customize those Greymen during the week, and at the end of the event burn their own inner Greyman during 140 private rituals.In 2008 we protected the border between Dreams and Reality with the Department of Dreamland Security at Checkpoint Dreamyourtopia - a border control checkpoint to enter your own Dreams. A year later we tore down the walls between Dreams and Reality in an old swimming pool in Berlin with chainsaws and sledgehammers, exactly twenty years after the Berlin Wall fell.In 2011 people could sign a Spiritual Karma Laundering contract at the Exchanghibition Bank. That would bring their spiritual Karma debt back to Zero, and in return they'd get a Zero banknote.In 2012 the Exchanghibition Banknotes were hanging as leaves from the branches of the Transformoney Tree. But even if in the future Virtual Reality will have more pixels than Reality itself, will that make VR more realistic than Reality?

story:
One of the most important things to ever be told is that your loved and accepted. The world is way too small for hate. We all need to come together and start a movement against hate, bullying, and help end teen suicide. The rate of death is higher now then its ever been. Not all people who hurt look sad. A lot hide their pain with a fake smile and then it's too late.

 

Last year we were in the Dallas pride parade. I held a small sign that simply said "it's ok to be different"  because it is ok and people need to know its ok. Thousands of people saw that sign and told me, "Thank you". It touched their hearts. It was raining that day, yet thousands came out to show support anyway. It didn't stop anyone. I didn't have an umbrella and a lady I had never seen came up to me and gave me hers. At one point prior to the parade beginning, I was holding my sign and a little girl about 4 or 5 years old came running up to me with her parents chasing behind her. She ran up and said "I love you" and gave me a huge hug. Right then I knew how it felt to be accepted. This little girl did not know me and told me she loved me. I want to share that love. Last week I thought to myself, "What if I get a group together to march in the parade with us and carry a huge banner saying 'It's OK 2B Different' and 'More love. Less hate.', and then everyone have a sign that says something that they want the world to - know something from the heart - but I can't afford to do it on my own so I'm asking for help.

 

The entry fee is $300 and it's another $150 to throw beads and then the cost of the large banner for the front. We have not yet gotten a price on that, and if we can't do it that's ok, but it certainly won't be from lack of trying. Any donation is welcome, anything at all. You can donate under your name or you can do it anonymously. It's up to you. If you need any more info, please contact me. If you would like to see photos from last year, let me know.

Thank you, love and light and many blessings to come.

story:
WHO WE ARE

BABY CAGES, Heather Rappard, and Non·plus' Justin Lees dream of DARK ARTS, an amalgum of sound, fashion and video. A love song for the underbelly of Nova Scotia's arts scenes, DARK ARTS celebrates Non·plus' summer line of winter-inspired clothes, BABY CAGES' homecoming, and Heather Rappards's ingenuitive mindseye.

BABY CAGES is artist/musician Halloway Jones. She crafts gloomy pop songs using heavily distorted guitar and vocals, accompanied by the psychedelic organ sounds of Jeremy Costello (Special Costello, Deep Conditions). Together the pair recorded their debut album ‘i’m so sorry’ which was greeted with international praise— London-based DUMMY mag called the album “striking… the pearl of something true amongst the grit.”

 

Heather Rappard uses video and film to beautifully depict the abstract narratives of music. Her images are dreamlike and surreal, adding layers of meaning and intrigue to the songs they accompany. Her videos have appeared on Noisey, Weird Canada, Stereogum, Impose, Hartzine, and at festivals such as Pop Montreal, OBEY Convention, Atlantic Film Festival, Halifax Independent Film Festival, and Halifax Pop Explosion.

Non·plus is derived from the Latin term for "no more" combined with the French word for "neither." Justin Lee’s dark androgynous clothing is both neither and no more. After falling in love with leather, denim and chiffon, Lees changed his course of study from Film to Fashion, and produced his first collection titled “Second Cousins of the Anti-Christ”. He continues to study at NSCAD University, exploring and expanding on his genderless gothic aesthetic.

DARK ARTS will premeire at the rebirth of Pigeon Gallery in August 2013, the gallery will display the new Non·plus body of work and The Bus Stop Theatre will host a performance from BABY CAGES.  

WHY WE NEED YOU

We believe the arts would die without supportive communities, so we look to our community in order to execute the aesthetic we envision. The funds we raise will go towards purchasing fabrics, film gear, and studio space. 

For your contributions, we offer our talents. Ranging from:

  • BABY CAGES cassettes, t-shirts, and rare live performances
  • Unique handcrafted accessories from Non·plus 
  • Hand made booklets and drawings by Halloway Jones
  • A BABY CAGES song written about YOU

HELP US

Please consider backing our project and choose a reward level that fits your budget. If you are without contirbutable funds, you can support this project by sharing our campaign with your friends, colleagues, and family on Facebook and on Twitter (#DARKARTS). We are so grateful for your time and support.

xo

BABY CAGES, Heather Rappard & Justin Lees (Non·plus)

story:
Flor de Muerto, “Flowers of the Dead” is Victoria's CORE project for 2013.
Description
Victoria’s CORE 2013 Project

Victoria’s CORE Project is one which represents both our city as a region, as well as tying in with Burning Man’s Cargo Cult theme. Victoria is known as a floral city, and often referred to as the “City of Gardens.” Our bloom count is an aspect of our city which attracts millions of tourists every year to Victoria, and our city spends an astronomical amount of money annually in order to maintain that reputation. 

Our reputation of a Floral City is also representative colonialism as well. When European colonization began, many plants and flowers that were brought over from other by colonizers wiped out many of the indigenous plants to Victoria. Colonialism is a predominant theme in Burning Man’s Cargo Cult theme, which discusses the ways in which American GI’s came to new land bringing riches, and left empty beer cans and garbage. 

This year’s CORE project features 3 flowers: the Camas flower, which was eaten by many Indigenous people in Victoria; the Opium Flower, as Victoria was the second largest producer of Opium in the world up until the mid 1800’s, and the Dogwood flower, which is BC’s provincial flower. This art piece will be interactive, and allow people to walk or climb from bloom to bloom up to the highest lookout point, which will be about approximately 17ft high, boasting an amazing view of the playa.
 
Your awesome 2013 CoRE team are....
 

Build lead:  Fletcher.

Artistic lead: Sweet Dee

Fundraising: Chipmunk and Sweet Dee

Finance: Mira Bell

Volunteer coordinator: Shenanigans

Fire Leads: X-ray November & Fehkor MacFakerson
 
Fire Perimeter: Funker Fae

story:
Update:

WE MADE IT! We funded the show I was asking for help with! Amazing! in less than two days I was able to secure the place to house the launch of this show that means so much to me! 
BUT BUT there's MORE! 
I am looking at a second venue on the eastern side of the country! 
Lets take this momentum and Help me take this show all over the world!

My goal is to show my work to everyone. This show is an amazing way to get quilts in front of so many folks! 
Lets double what we started! 

Project Summary:

This the place where I tell you in a few words what it has taken me 33 years to work up to. 

I am a maker and innovator. 

I come from a background in architecture and design and have been working in the medium of quilts for the past 13 years. 

I have created 50 quilts and I am going to create an exhibition of them February 18th of next year so I can share it with you and the world. 

This is the latest and my greatest example of what I am learning and creating. 

I want to share with you the ways that a medium can transform past our preconceptions. I have learned SO much in creating these 50 quilts. I want to bring that to you. 

To do that I need a space and lights and photographers and transportation [and a few libations to make it into a dance party]

With your help I can bring this exhibition to fruition. 

What We Need & What You Get

With your help I want to raise $8,000 to fund all the parts of this exhibition of these pieces. From the venue to the lighting [who knew that was so expensive?!] to the vans to get people there. 

I am also hiring and bribing and coercing several photographers to help me with this show. I want images of it to help spread the word. Good photos will help change the craft vernacular towards "sculpture".  I think this is paramount in quilting becoming understood in its true form. 

What I am offering in exchange for your help is a few AWESOME STELLAR things and opportunities! 

#LCoDJ swag is nothing to shake a stick at. 

We have some hand written cards [by me] and some pretty awesome compositions by REALLY talented photographers [no, I didn't take them, but that is kind of you to assume]. 

Also a VIP tour of the show guided and narrated by the artist with wine and snacks. 

PLUS a few pre-sales of the quilts themselves for far less than they will be priced once they are done touring the world.

And a few more things check out the boxes to the right!


The Impact

The reason I am doing this show is to create a series of works that visually explains the space between function and art and pushes the medium of "quilt" out of the realm of being relegated to the "domestic" and the [untrue] thoughts that they are monetarily valueless. 

Quilts are important. Our global experience of textiles is important. I want to create an exhibition where that is the singular experience. 

The artist Donald Judd, for whom the title takes its name, is a sculptor who's works are entirely about materials in environment. I chose to allude to his oeuvre with this series to illustrate the simple yet paramount task of this show: to take the focus of the viewing audience to the basic elements of a quilt. 

The defining elements of this show are as follows:

The "Log cabin" block is arguably the most basic repeatable quilt-block unit so by using it I am working with the basic alphabet of patchwork. 

I am also relegated to only black and white fabric after the red of the centers, which makes the pieces studies in graphic form and iteration rather than in colors and those relationships. 

The quilting on each follows the same rules so that it doesn't add any variation to the already varied explorations in changes within the blocks and the orientation. 

They are each the same size 90" square

all the materials are reclaimed discarded textiles. 

I have chosen materials and form and shape that are the most palatable to the viewer and to the concepts of the medium thereby allowing them to explore the intricacies of the  textures of the materials and the variation within each piece. 


Risks & Challenges

I am funding this whole show myself. 

I have used over a ton of materials in the construction of these 50 quilts. Over 2000 pounds of textiles saved from scraps or landfills as well 2000 pounds of textures with existing stories and histories from their usages. 

There is a great deal of expense in creating these projects. 

I AM ASKING FOR YOUR HELP TO GET THESE WORKS INTO THE PUBLIC EYE. 

Having help to get these works out there will greatly aid me in pushing the conversations that I am working with into the greater consciousness. 

I started a career in quilting while helping on a ranch in central Oregon and lived in a friend's garage in Seattle for years till I was able to move on and have my own studio. Since then I have continued to grow my business and passionately pursue my work on the concepts within the medium. I have worked many many hours to get where I am. There are still many many to go. 

Having the support of my community [YOU] makes it all worth it and possible. 


Other Ways You Can Help

There's a myriad of different ways to contribute

Tell your friends. [preferably the wealthy altruistic types]

Come to the show! 

If you arent in LA help me find a venue near you. [ask your local museum to bring my show to you. I can provide any and all info they will need for that]

Or just send me a word of encouragement. [I need that sometimes.]

Since then I have continued to grow my business and passionately pursue my work on the concepts within the medium. I have worked many many hours to get where I am. There are still many many to go. 
Having the support of my community [YOU] makes it all worth it and possible. 





Other Ways You Can Help

There's a myriad of different ways to contribute
Tell your friends. [preferably the wealthy altruistic types]
Come to the show! 
If you arent in LA help me find a venue near you. [ask your local museum to bring my show to you. I can provide any and all info they will need for that]
Or just send me a word of encouragement. [I need that sometimes.]

story:
I'm Lauren Onça O'Leary, artist, and I love Krampus. I've spent all year working to make "A Krampus Carol: Create Your Own Adventure Coloring Book" a reality by November 30, 2016. 

Who is Krampus, you say? He's the charming alpine Anti-Hero of the winter holidays. He's the horned Wild Man who accompanies good St. Nick on his rounds, and instead of giving out presents, he carries a switch and carts off the naughty in his magic sack. (It's bigger on the inside, of course.) He is the cure for everything sicky-sweet and saccharine about Christmas, and because of that, his fans are now increasingly worldwide. He's cheeky, hunky, and wicked for the Good Cause of Being Bad.

As Oscar Wilde said of the Greek's goat-foot God, Pan, "This modern world hath need of thee."

What is this "A Krampus Carol" project?

Firstly, it is a fun and folky coloring book on the delightful theme of Krampus, increasingly global Alpine folk anti-hero of the winter holidays. And coloring is what everyone with too much to do is doing to chill out. And nobody is more chill than a snow monster! The images are rendered in "Scratchbord", a new medium for me, which gives it a slightly medieval, eerie, dark-and-tingle-y quality. The art is family friendly, totally PG, and with lots of textures for the avid colorist.
Secondly, it's a fun 'Create-Your-Own-Adventure' story, exploring aspects of the Krampus mythos with a tender archetypal bent. He plays 'bad cop' to goodie-two-shoes St. Nick, and allows the ancient character of the Wild Man a toehold in this modern world. The concept of the story is definitely for the Young Adult and Adult set, but again, it's totally PG.
Thirdly, it comes with an appendix of lyrics and sheet music for a zesty original Krampus-tide holiday carol. You'll soon see video on the crowdfunding site of folks rocking out to it!

The art is nearly complete (1 image left to go), and the text is done. The coloring book will have about 30 pages of combined images and prose. Awesome Richmond, VA artist Steven Warrick is again on board doing layout for this project. We've also had great editing support from Dana Jones of Lynchburg Tribal. I am proud of this work, and believe it adds something worthy and unique to the booming subculture of Krampus worldwide.

I am an established artist and writer, having created a massive body of mythic art for the World Spirit Tarot and the World Spirit Tarot Adult Coloring Book, both of which you can learn more about here on IndieGoGo. I also produce festivals and teach dance and stagecraft, so I live to promote the arts and get things done.

On a more personal note, making this Krampus art has saved my sanity. I'm a performer, teacher, and community gal, but the devastating illness of my teenage son has pulled me from the stage and the classroom and into a much more isolated and medicalized life. Making art from the wry, tongue-in-cheek hedonism of Krampus and the myths surrounding him has allowed me to remain creatively ALIVE. I was able to carry on this work in even the most soul-deadening hospitals, terrifying bedside vigils and during the relentless grind that is medical advocacy in the American health care system. (Which does not work perfectly, by the way.) 

$3000 covers two sets of costs:

-This Project - The cost of art materials, paying for layout, transcription of the sheet music by a professional, basic PR, the first printing of these new books, shipping, perks and

-Two Donations - I'm going to donate 5% of funds raised here to two organizations doing good work that touches. One is Santa's Cause!, a 501(c)(3) non-profit, all-volunteer organization providing gifts from Santa to kids who would otherwise have none. They have worked with DC's KrampusNacht and have their confidence, and given how rough last year was with my own son, I want to pay it forward.  The other is RVA Krampusnacht!, the local group which organizes the epic KrampusWalk in Richmond, where I live, and works all year to spread the good word about this therapeutically saucy historical figure.  

PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD ABOUT THIS PROJECT:

If you have an affinity for Krampus, for kids facing tough times, or just know people or events who do, please share this around. We can make some awesomeness for everyone.

And maybe the Krampus Carol lyric and music in the back of the book will become a regular part of the holiday/anti-holiday festivities at your house, just like mine!

story:
We are two Contemporary Art students at Gray's School of Art. We feel the student art scenery in Aberdeen is not strong enough yet, so we are hoping to make a difference by starting this project.
The focus of this Zine will be on creating a vibrant art platform in the Aberdeen Student community.
We are starting this because we feel that this is still missing in Aberdeen.
We want to invite students to collaborate with us by sending us their artworks. These artworks can be anything, the only requirement is that is has to be related to the monthly theme.
Our Zine will be different from others in a way that it is not self-centered and will focus on developing as many young individuals as possible. Furthermore it will be purely concentrated on uniting the Aberdeen art scenery.
We have started this Indiegogo campaign, because without the funding we won’t be able to develop the project on a bigger scale. The following things will be done with the raised money: 

The following things will be done with the raised money:
 - Printing and publishing the ZINE
- Promoting the Zine through creating a professional website
 - Advertising the Zine through magazines/newspapers
At first we will give the ZINE’s away for free. If the project will start to have a stable base, we will take it to the next level and start selling the ZINE’s in order to raise money to create ZINE-related projects. Such as: exhibitions, performances and art symposiums.
The main risk will be not getting sufficient funding for publishing enough copies of the ZINE to create an awareness in the Aberdeen Student Scenery.

story:
Whats up with the indiegogo, brobro? :o

I've asked friends and family to donate to my Cintiq Companion 2 fund in lieu of birthday presents or beers.

Why do you want it? :|

Because drawing on a Cintiq is like drawing on dream clouds straight from your third eye hole. Here is a video of it in action: (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=knmO9tTcFgc I) currently own a dying Wacom Intuos 3, which is a sort of an ancient digital drawing tablet that feels like drawing on a fish with another fish. The Cintiq companion I can take anywhere, so I can literally work on art any time, anywhere. I can even animate on the danged thing.

What else? Make me feel bad. :(

I've been hit with a lot of financial challenges this year (namely, helping support my disabled parents and unemployed brother as they moved to Texas), while at the same time owning up to and battling my depression. I realize drawing is great therapy for me, but self motivation becomes difficult when I have experienced how much easier drawing can be with the equipment at work. Plus I love hanging out away from my computer with my girlfriend after work and paper sketchbooks are so 1500's. There, I said it.

I don't know you, show me some of your art. >:)

Check out (https://www.facebook.com/EricDrobile/)  to see a wide variety of illustration styles. Most of all I am trying to finish my animated comic Merry Melony: (http://www.merrymelony.com/) You can also take a look a look at my 3D animation reel here, which contains clips from The Book of Life, Looney Tunes, and (Freebirds: https://vimeo.com/115732193)

I'd like to help you, but I can't. ;(

If you have friends that support the arts (and by arts, I mean one lone needy artist), absolutely! But if you think you'll just annoy your friends then save them from the spam. :)

Thanks guys!

story:
My name is Monika Stockton Maddux

I am a 3rd year Master of Fine Arts Candidate at Wichita State University. I have lived in Wichita, Kansas my entire life and plan to open a business in Wichita upon completion of my MFA.

Artist Statement:

A recurring theme is my obsession. I have been unable to conceive and deliver a baby girl and a profound obsession has developed and festered.  Because my family is such an important part of my life, it is natural that it is the inspiration from which I draw, and this is reflected in my work. I am a mother to four boys and have no daughters. My work mirrors intense and deep emotions, it is from these emotions that I pull, and therefore enable, an emotion from the viewer; the type of emotion which is felt instinctively; that becomes visceral yet cognitively unattainable.

My content is uncomfortable and relatable. Focused on portraying the emotions conjured through reenactment and visual conversation, I begin with the seemingly mundane, and upon further investigation, end with overwhelming obsessiveness. This work is a progression that creates an environment where the viewer is confronted with passion and compulsion sparked by loss.

I transform the viewer’s perception of their size and place, in their environment, to position them into what entering my mind would be like. An encounter within the emotionally disturbed consciousness of a mother who has lost and is obsessed with these notions.

 

Exhibition Proposal:

In my last year as candidate, I intend to explore other avenues of making while maintaining the same narratives; motherhood, loss caused by miscarriage, obsession and its manifestations, desperation, dealing with resolution and hard adoptions of reality. I will continue to use textiles, ready-made objects from my childhood, furniture and building materials with my thesis exhibition consisting of 8 - 10 sculptures as a continuous body of work.

 

Research Concept:

My research is into the multiple aspects of motherhood, being a mother and having a mother. Being raised with sisters and raising only sons. Being a mother losing a daughter and being a daughter losing a mother. I continue to investigate obsession that develops in response to the psychological impact of loss, specifically the effects of miscarriage. To that I add an investigation about the desire to become like my mother and the inability to do the same mother/daughter things I had anticipated and the idea developing into an obsession.

I am curious about my need to produce a female offspring. I wonder if it stems from a maternal need, or if it is ingrained in me by society. I was either naturally predisposed to nurture or I was trained, beginning when I received my first doll that I named, cared for, and pretended was my own child. My mother had 3 daughters and she made matching dresses for them and I couldn’t wait until I had a daughter to wear my handmade dresses. Do I want to be like my mother or am I expected to be like my mother?
